{{Infobox civilian attack | title = 2000 Dharmapuri bus burning | image = Dharmapuri Bus Burning.jpg | image_size = 300px | alt = | caption = Bus burnt during Protests against [[Jayalalithaa]]'s conviction | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | location = [[Elakiyampatti]], [[Dharmapuri]], [[Tamil Nadu]], [[India]] | target = [[Tamil Nadu Agricultural University]] bus passengers | coordinates = | date = {{start date|2000|02|02|df=y}} | time = | timezone = | type = [[Arson]], [[mass murder]], | fatalities = 3 college girls | injuries = 16 college girls | perp = Muniappan, Nedunchezhian , Ravindran and D.K. Rajendran and 24 other [[AIADMK]] terrorists.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/chennai/TN-bus-burning-case-SC-commutes-death-sentence-of-3-to-life/articleshow/51367261.cms | title=TN bus burning case: SC commutes death sentence of 3 to life | publisher=[[Times of India]] | date=12 March 2016 | accessdate=11 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-28-aiadmk-men-convicted-in-bus-burning-case-1080107 | title=28 AIADMK men convicted in bus burning case | publisher=DNA | date=15 February 1007 | accessdate=11 March 2016}}</ref> | weapons = [[Petrol bomb]] | motive = Protest against [[Jayalalithaa]]'s conviction in [[Pleasant Stay hotel case]] }} The '''Dharmapuri bus burning''' incident occurred on February 2, 2000 at Ilakiyampatti, on the outskirts of [[Dharmapuri]] in [[Tamil Nadu]], [[India]]. Three students from the [[Tamil Nadu Agricultural University]], [[Coimbatore]] were burned to death.<ref name="busburningincident">{{cite news|url=http://www.hinduonnet.com/2000/02/03/stories/01030005.htm |title=3 burnt alive |date=2000-02-03 |publisher=[[The Hindu]] |accessdate=2009-08-08 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jXX7yBMw?url=http://www.hinduonnet.com/2000/02/03/stories/01030005.htm |archivedate=2009-09-04 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> The [[Supreme Court of India]] initially convicted and sentenced the three main accused Muniappan, Nedunchezhian and Ravindran to death observing it was rarest of the rare and earlier the Salem District court had stated that crime was committed "only for the political career" .<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/Death-for-3-AIADMK-men-in-Dharmapuri-bus-burning-case/article14721821.ece | title=Death for 3 AIADMK men in Dharmapuri bus burning case | publisher=The Hindu | date=17 February 2007 | accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref> But it was commuted to life imprisonment by the three member bench headed by [[Ranjan Gogoi|Justice Gogoi]] after a review petition in which they accepted , the defence lawyer [[L. Nageswara Rao]]'s arguments who admitted that the three main accused had indeed taken petrol from a workshop and set fire to the bus which killed the girl students but stated the convicts were acting in mob frenzy and it was case of [[Diminished responsibility]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.huffingtonpost.in/suchitra-vijayan/dharmapuri-bus-burning-a-_b_9556544.html | title=Wait, Murderous Bus-Burning AIADMK Members Were 'Victims' Of Mob-Think? The Apex Court Thinks So | publisher=Huffington Post | work=Suchitra Vijayan | date=15 July 2016 | accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/news-ians/dharmapuri-bus-burning-sc-commutes-death-sentence-to-life-imprisonment-116031100989_1.html | title=Dharmapuri bus burning: SC commutes death sentence to life imprisonment | publisher=[[Business Standard]] | date=11 March 2016 | accessdate=11 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://blogs.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/tracking-indian-communities/sc-ruling-on-dharmapuri-bus-burning-a-misinterpretation/ | title=SC ruling on Dharmapuri bus burning a misinterpretation | publisher=[[The Times of India]] | work=K M Vijayan | date=23 March 2016 | accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref><ref name="diminished">{{cite web | url=https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/SC-commutes-death-penalty-of-Dharmapuri-bus-burning-convicts-to-life/article14149682.ece | title=SC commutes death penalty of Dharmapuri bus burning convicts to life | publisher=The Hindu | date=11 March 2016 | accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref> Tamil Nadu government had recommended the premature release Muniappan, Nedunchezhian and Ravindran ,the [[List of governors of Tamil Nadu|Tamil Nadu Governor]] [[Banwarilal Purohit]] rejects the recommendation but the [[Edappadi K Palaniswami]] government again recommends there release and the Governor approves it and they was freed from [[Vellore Central Prison|Vellore Jail]] .<ref>{{cite web | url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/chennai/dharmapuri-bus-burning-case-three-life-convicts-released-from-vellore-jail/articleshow/66691136.cms | title=Dharmapuri bus burning case: Three life convicts released from Vellore Jail | publisher=[[The Times of India]] | work=Shanmughasundaram J | date=19 November 2018 | accessdate=19 November 2018}}</ref>
== Background == Soon after the [[Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam]] party (DMK) came into power in Tamil Nadu in 1996, it filed a series of corruption cases against the former [[Chief Minister of Tamil Nadu|Chief Minister]] and [[All India Anna Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam]] (AIADMK) general secretary [[J. Jayalalithaa]], other ministers, and bureaucrats of her government. In the [[Pleasant Stay hotel case]], a Special Court judgement given by Justice V. Radhakrishnan convicted Jayalalithaa and sentenced her to one year of "rigorous imprisonment".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hinduonnet.com/2000/02/03/stories/01030004.htm|title=Jayalalitha convicted in hotel case |date=2000-02-03|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=2009-08-08}}</ref> This led to statewide protests and violence, including damage to public property by AIADMK members.<ref name="statevoilence">{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/2000/02/03/stories/04032231.htm |title=HOTEL CASE VERDICT: AIADMK volunteers go berserk |date=2000-02-03 |publisher=The Hindu |accessdate=2009-08-08 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jXX8MV2I?url=http://www.hindu.com/2000/02/03/stories/04032231.htm |archivedate=2009-09-04 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> The Protests in Elakiyampatti in [[Dharmapuri]] were led by AIADMK Dharmapuri union secretary D.K. Rajendran along with other AIADMK party workers including Nedu alias Nedunchezhiyan, then secretary of the Dharmapuri town unit Madhu alias Ravindran, MGR forum functionary, and P Muniappan, a former panchayat president.<ref name="amma">{{cite web | url=http://epaper.timesofindia.com/Repository/getFiles.asp?Style=OliveXLib:LowLevelEntityToPrint_ETNEW&Type=text/html&Locale=english-skin-custom&Path=ETM/2010/08/31&ID=Ar00300 | title=SC upholds death for Amma’s boys 3 AIADMK Workers Who Burnt Alive College Girls During Protest Against Jaya’s Conviction Join Death Row | publisher=[[The Times of India]] | work=Sanjay K Singh | date=7 September 2010 | accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref>
== Incident == Seventy students from the Tamil Nadu Agricultural University, Coimbatore, were returning from a study tour on two buses with boys and girls in separate buses.While returning they learn the news of Jayalalitha 's conviction in the [[Pleasant Stay hotel case]], Latha one of the lecturers accompanying the students telephones the Vice Chancellor of [[Tamil Nadu Agricultural University]] who asks them to go a safe place and travel back to Coimbatore after normally returns.Accordingly they attempt to take the buses to the District Collector’s office.However they unable to go there due to traffic being obstructed due to road roko agitation by AIADMK party men led by Dharmapuri union secretary D.K. Rajendran in violation of prohibitory orders.<ref name="amma" /><ref name="Firstaccused">{{cite web | url=https://www.thehindu.com/2000/04/29/stories/04292233.htm | title=AIADMK members among 31 chargesheeted | publisher=The Hindu | date=29 April 2000 | accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref> AIADMK party workers threw [[petrol bomb]]s inside the bus carrying girls even through it was full of girls with over 44 girls and 2 lecturers <ref name="lava">{{cite web | url=https://www.deccanchronicle.com/nation/in-other-news/040316/was-upset-with-jaya-conviction-plead-3-aiadmk-men-on-death-row-for-burning-bus.html | title=Was upset with Jaya conviction, plead 3 AIADMK men on death row for burning bus | publisher=Deccan Chronicle | work=J VENKATESAN | date=4 March 2016 | accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref> and the front-side of the bus caught fire spreading backwards as the back door was locked keys were not handily available , lecturers Latha and Akila and some students manage to come out and through boys from the other bus manage to break the backdoor and pull out some of the girls the fire had spread fast and three girls, Hemalatha from [[Chennai]], V. Gayathri from [[Virudhachalam]] and Kokilavani from [[Namakkal]] were burned to death, and 16 others were injured.<ref name="SCcase1">{{cite web | url=https://sci.gov.in/jonew/judis/36747.pdf | title=IN THE SUPREME COURT OF INDIA CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION CRIMINAL APPEAL NOS. 127–130 OF 2008 | publisher=Supreme Court of India | accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rediff.com/news/2000/feb/04nadar.htm | title=They burnt to death in front of our eyes' | publisher=Rediff News | work=A G Nadar | accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.thehindu.com/2005/03/22/stories/2005032206040500.htm | title=Witnesses recall Dharmapuri bus burning incident | publisher=The Hindu | date=22 May 2005 | accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref><ref name="busburningincident"/> The scenes of the bus burning were captured and broadcast the following day on [[Sun TV (India)|Sun TV]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/2005/06/22/stories/2005062206970500.htm|title=Sun TV news editor deposes in bus-burning trial|date=2005-06-22|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=2009-08-13}}</ref>
== Aftermath == The incident caused anger amongst the student community. Schools and colleges were asked to shut for a week, and students across the state held silent processions and protest marches condemning the act.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/2000/feb/04tn.htm |title=Schools and colleges ordered shut in Tamil Nadu |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jXX8kzsx?url=http://www.rediff.com/news/2000/feb/04tn.htm |archivedate=2009-09-04 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-08-24 |df= }}</ref> Chief Minister [[M. Karunanidhi]] ordered a [[Crime Branch CID|CB-CID]] investigation. Jayalalithaa demanded a [[Central Bureau of Investigation|CBI]] probe for a fair trial.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hinduonnet.com/thehindu/2000/02/04/stories/04042231.htm|title=Bus burning incident: Jayalalithaa demands CBI inquiry |date=2000-02-04|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=2009-08-13}}</ref> During the initial trial held at [[Krishnagiri]] court, 20 witnesses became hostile.N.P. Veerasamy the father of Kokilavani one of the girls burnt alive appealed in the [[Madras High Court]] seeking a transfer of the case from [[Dharmapuri]] as the [[AIADMK]] had returned to power in Tamil Nadu and the prosecutor of the case was appointed by it and accused were AIADMK functionaries and party activists.Accepting his appeal the [[Madras High Court]] halted the trial and High court Judge V. Kanagaraj calling the trial a `colossal failure and eyewash' he scarped it and ordered a re-trial at [[Salem, Tamil Nadu|Salem]] court.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.thehindu.com/2003/09/20/stories/2003092006520100.htm | title=HC scraps 'eyewash' of bus burning trial | publisher=The Hindu | date=20 September 2003 | accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://epaper.timesofindia.com/Repository/ml.asp?Ref=VE9JQ0gvMjAxMC8wOC8zMSNBcjAwNzAw&Mode=HTML&Locale=english-skin-custom | title=How the bus burning case victims got justice HC Shifted Trial From Dharmapuri To A Salem Court | publisher=[[The Times of India]] | work=A Subramani | date=31 August 2010 | accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref> After a series of delays in appointing a special public prosecutor<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindu.com/2004/12/07/stories/2004120707640400.htm|title= Bus burning case: court directive to investigating agency |date=2004-12-07|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=2009-08-24}}</ref> and problems with missing case bundles,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindu.com/2005/02/18/stories/2005021809910100.htm|title=Bus burning case bundles missing?|date=2005-02-18|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=2009-08-24}}</ref> the trial progressed slowly. Seven years after the incident, on 15 February 2007, the Salem court sentenced 3 AIADMK men to death and 25 others to seven years imprisonment.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/death-for-three-aiadmk-members/33712-3.html |title=Death for three AIADMK members |date=2007-02-16 |publisher=[[CNN IBN]] |accessdate=2009-08-24 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jXX98mnm?url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/death-for-three-aiadmk-members/33712-3.html |archivedate=2009-09-04 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Two others were acquitted, and one person died during the course of the investigation.The judgment was upheld by Madras High Court on December 6, 2007,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/madras-hc-upholds-death-penalty-to-aiadmk-men/53690-3.html|title=Madras HC upholds death penalty to AIADMK men|date=2007-12-06|publisher=CNN IBN|accessdate=2009-08-24}}</ref> subsequently by the Supreme Court on August 30, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-08-30/india/28285555_1_dharmapuri-bus-aiadmk-workers-death-sentence|title=Dharmapuri bus burning case: SC upholds death for three AIADMK workers|date=2010-08-30|publisher=Times of India|accessdate=2010-08-30}}</ref> and later upholding the execution of 3.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/tamil-nadu/dharmapuri-bus-burning-sc-stays-execution-of-3_683561.html|title=Dharmapuri bus burning: SC stays execution of 3|date=2011-01-28|publisher=Zee news|accessdate=2013-01-07}}</ref> But it was commuted to life imprisonment after the Defence lawyers L. Nageswara Rao and Sushil Kumar accepted that the AIADMK mob had set fire to the bus but said that the accused only wanted to damage buses and that killing was not pre-planned but a spur of the moment reaction and the [[Supreme Court of India]] accepted the argument of [[Diminished responsibility]] .<ref name="lava"/><ref name="diminished" /> Dharmapuri AIADMK leader D.K. Rajendran and the first accused in the case the then union secretary for Dharmapuri who organised the road roko protest and was originally convicted for 7 years which was later reduced to 2 years courted controversy when it was found he was holding four positions cooperative milk society and he resigned after the [[Madras High Court]] "deep anguish and displeasure" that a convict could hold positions despite being statutory disqualified due to his conviction.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/chennai/First-accused-in-Dharmapuri-bus-burning-case-quits-posts/articleshow/25220172.cms | title=First accused in Dharmapuri bus burning case quits posts | publisher=[[The Times of India]] | work=A Subramani | date=4 November 2013 | accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref><ref name="SCcase1" /><ref name="Firstaccused" /> A granite structure has been built as a memorial for with names of V. Gayatri, K. Hemalatha and V. Kokilavani engraved for the dead girls in the Tamil Nadu Agricultural University hostel.The girls were aged 20 years at the time of the incident.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-tamilnadu/TNAU-students-pay-homage-to-bus-burning-victims/article14721873.ece | title=TNAU students pay homage to bus burning victims | publisher=The Hindu | date=17 February 2007 | accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref>
The Tamil Government actually ruled by AIADMK tries to release the three persons involved in this case. Accordingly to prison sources, at least 1,500 prisoners will get the benefit of the general amnesty of the Tamil nadu government. And this list contained these three person (Muniappan, Nedunchezhian and Ravindran) who seems to be AIADMK party members, a tactial and silent move by AIADMK to release their party members. On 19-11-2018, AIADMK men convicted in Dharmapuri college bus burning case set free. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/aiadmk-men-convicted-in-dharmapuri-college-bus-burning-case-set-free/article25537054.ece|title=AIADMK men convicted in Dharmapuri college bus burning case set free|date=2019-11-19|publisher=The Hindu India|accessdate=2018-11-19}}</ref>
== In popular culture == The [[Tamil language]] film ''[[Kalloori]]'' was released in December 2007, just days before the Madras High court upheld the judgment of Salem court. The movie is about college life, and climaxed with a bus burning incident. Following public and media demands, the ending was changed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://in.movies.yahoo.com/news-detail/15327/Kalloori-different-climax.html|title=Kalloori, with a different climax!|date=2007-12-19|publisher=Yahoo Movies India|accessdate=2009-08-24}}</ref>

{{Use Australian English|date=November 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Australian National Audit Office |logo = [[File:Australian_National_Audit_Office_Logo.png]] |logo_width = |picture = Australian National Audit Office in Barton.jpg |picture_caption= ANAO located in the Centenary House building in [[Barton, Australian Capital Territory]]. |formed = 1901 |jurisdiction = {{AUS}} |employees = 348 (estimate for 2013–14){{cite web|title=Budget Paper No. 1|url=http://www.budget.gov.au/2013-14/content/bp1/html/bp1_bst6-04.htm|work=2013-14 Commonwealth Budget|publisher=Australian Government|author=Australian Government|location=Statement 6: Expenses and Net Capital Investment|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130924130405/http://www.budget.gov.au/2013-14/content/bp1/html/bp1_bst6-04.htm|archivedate=24 September 2013}} |budget = {{AUD}}77.651 million (2012) |minister1_name = |minister1_pfo = |chief1_name = Grant Hehir |chief1_position=
Auditor-General |parent_agency = [[Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet (Australia)|Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet]] |website = {{URL|http://www.anao.gov.au/}} |footnotes = {{cite web |url=http://www.anao.gov.au/~/media/Files/Annual%20Reports/Annual%20Reports/2011_2012_Annual_Report/ANAO%20Annual%20Report%202011%202012.pdf |format=PDF |title=The Auditor-General Annual Report 2011−2012 |work=Australian National Audit Office |publisher=Commonwealth of Australia |date= |accessdate=4 November 2012 |isbn=0-642-81266-7 }} }} The '''Australian National Audit Office''' ('''ANAO''') is the national [[auditor]] for the [[Parliament of Australia]] and [[Government of Australia]]. It reports directly to the Australian Parliament via the [[Speaker of the Australian House of Representatives|Speaker of the House of Representatives]] and the [[President of the Australian Senate|President of the Senate]]. Administratively, the ANAO is located in the [[List of Australian Commonwealth Government entities#Portfolio of Prime Minister and Cabinet|Prime Minister and Cabinet portfolio]]. The current Auditor-General of Australia is Grant Hehir. == Role == The Australian National Audit Office is a specialist [[government agency|public sector agency]] that supports the Auditor-General of Australia, who is an independent officer of the Parliament of Australia. The main functions and powers of the Auditor-General under the {{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|act||Auditor-General Act 1997}} include auditing financial statements of Commonwealth agencies, authorities, companies and their subsidiaries in accordance with the {{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|act||Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997}} and conducting performance audits which are tabled in Parliament. The Auditor-General may report its findings directly to Parliament or to a Minister, on any important matter. In addition, the ANAO plays a leadership role in improving public administration and audit capability in Australia and overseas by publishing information such as better practice guides and deploying experienced staff to audit institutions in [[Indonesia]] and [[Papua New Guinea]]. == Auditor-General == The Auditor-General is appointed by the Governor-General on the recommendation of the Minister, for a term of ten years. The current Auditor-General is Grant Hehir, who was appointed on 11 June 2015. Below is a full list of Commonwealth Auditors-General dating from 1902.{{citation|url=http://www.anao.gov.au/About-Us/History-of-the-ANAO|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140328061917/http://anao.gov.au/About-Us/History-of-the-ANAO|archivedate=28 March 2014|title=History of the ANAO|publisher=Australian National Audit Office|year=2014}} {| class="wikitable" ! Name || Dates |- |[[John William Israel]] {{post-nominals|post-noms=[[Imperial Service Order|ISO]]}}|| 1902{{spaced endash}}1926 |- |[[Charles Cerutty]] {{post-nominals|country=AUS|CMG}} || 1926{{spaced endash}}1935 |- |[[Herbert Charles Brown (public servant)|Herbert Charles Brown]] {{post-nominals|country=AUS|CBE}} || 1935{{spaced endash}}1938 |- |[[Ralph Abercrombie (public servant)|Ralph Abercrombie]] {{post-nominals|country=AUS|OBE}} || 1938{{spaced endash}}1946 |- |[[Albert Charles Joyce]] {{post-nominals|country=AUS|CBE}} || 1946{{spaced endash}}1951 |- |[[James Brophy (public servant)|James Brophy]] {{post-nominals|post-noms=[[Imperial Service Order|ISO]]}} || 1951{{spaced endash}}1955 |- |[[Harold Clive Newman]] {{post-nominals|country=AUS|CBE}} || 1955{{spaced endash}}1961 |- |[[Vic Skermer|Victor John William Skermer]] {{post-nominals|country=AUS|CBE}} || 1961{{spaced endash}}1973 |- |Duncan Robert Steele Craik {{post-nominals|country=AUS|OBE|CB}} || 1973{{spaced endash}}1981 |- |Keith Frederick Brigden {{post-nominals|country=AUS|AO}} || 1981{{spaced endash}}1985 |- |John Vincent Monaghan {{post-nominals|country=AUS|AO}} || 1985{{spaced endash}}1987 |- |[[John Taylor (public servant)|John Casey Taylor]] {{post-nominals|country=AUS|AO}} || 1988{{spaced endash}}1995 |- |Patrick Joseph Barrett {{post-nominals|country=AUS|AO}} || 1995{{spaced endash}}2005 |- |Ian McPhee {{post-nominals|country=AUS|sep=,|AO|PSM}} || 2005{{spaced endash}}2015 |- |Grant Hehir || 2015{{spaced endash}}''present'' |- |} == History == The ''Audit Act 1901''{{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|act||Audit Act 1901}} was the fourth piece of legislation passed by the Parliament. The Audit Act provided a legislative basis for the financial management of Commonwealth finances and the audit of related accounts, it also provided a legal foundation for the appointment of an Auditor-General.{{cite web |url=http://www.aph.gov.au/house/committee/jcpaa/agact/report/fullreport.pdf |format=PDF |title=Report 419: Inquiry into the ''Auditor-General Act 1997'' |publisher=Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit |year=2010 |location=Canberra |page=1}} The first Auditor-General, John William Israel,{{cite web |url=http://www.anao.gov.au/About-Us/History-of-the-ANAO |title=History of the ANAO |publisher=Australian National Audit Office |year=2011 |location=Canberra |page=1 |access-date=16 December 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140328061917/http://anao.gov.au/About-Us/History-of-the-ANAO |archive-date=28 March 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} began establishing the Federal Audit Office in 1902 in Melbourne.{{cite web |url=http://eprints.qut.edu.au/3604/1/3604.pdf |format=PDF |title=A Reactive Administrative Culture? The Legacy of Australia's first Auditor-General on the Australian Audit Office |author=Wanna, John |author2=Ryan, Christine |publisher=[[Australian Journal of Politics and History]] |year=2003 |location=Canberra |page=5}} The office moved to Canberra in 1935, in line with Government policy at that time. The ''Audit Act 1901'' was amended in 1979 to allow the Audit Office to undertake performance audits ("efficiency reviews").{{citation|url=http://www.anao.gov.au/~/media/Uploads/Speeches/2011/Senate%20Occasional%20Lecture%2014%20October%2011.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140211204129/http://www.anao.gov.au/~/media/Uploads/Speeches/2011/Senate%20Occasional%20Lecture%2014%20October%2011.pdf|page=6|title=Senate Occasional Lecture: The Evolving Role and Mandate of the ANAO Since Federation|first=Ian|last=McPhee|date=14 October 2011|archivedate=11 February 2014}} Efficiency reviews, or [[performance audit]], concerns the efficiency and effectiveness of a particular government activity. The ''Audit Act 1901'' was replaced with the ''Auditor-General Act 1997'',{{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|act||Auditor-General Act 1997}} which came into effect on 1 January 1998. The main features of the new act included: * provisions that strengthened the independence of the Auditor-General and the Australian National Audit Office; * the strengthening of the Auditor-General's role as an external auditor of Commonwealth agencies, authorities, companies and their subsidiaries, including a comprehensive mandate to conduct, with some limited exceptions, financial statement and performance audits of all government entities; and * clarification of the Auditor-General's mandate and powers.{{cite web |url=http://aph.gov.au/house/committee/jcpaa/Auditor-GeneralActReview/Frontpages.pdf |format=PDF |title=Report 386: Review of the Auditor-General Act 1997 |publisher=Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit |year=2001 |location=Canberra |page=3}} In 1986 the ANAO hosted XII [[International Congress of Supreme Audit Institutions|INCOSAI]], the twelfth triennial convention of the [[International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions]]. The Australian National Audit Office also reviews Commonwealth Government agencies pursuant to the {{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|act||Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997}} for the proper use and management of public money, public property and other Commonwealth resources; the {{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|act||Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act 1997}} that provides reporting, accountability and other rules for Commonwealth authorities and Commonwealth companies; and the {{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|act||Corporations Act 2001}} for general corporate law. == References == {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.anao.gov.au/ Australian National Audit Office] **[http://www.anao.gov.au/director/publications.cfm Latest Publications] [[Category:Commonwealth Government agencies of Australia]] [[Category:Government audit]] [[Category:Parliament of Australia]] [[Category:Auditing organizations]]

{{Infobox person |name = Bali White |image = Bali White.jpg |image_size = 200px |caption = Bali, 2012 |birth_place = [[Indianapolis, Indiana]] |other_names = |known_for = Human Rights Activism |occupation = Research Fellow, [[National Institutes of Health]] |nationality = United States |alma_mater = [[Columbia University]] |awards = see below |education = African, Environmental, Gender Studies }} '''Bali White''' (born January 10, [[Indianapolis, Indiana]]) is a researcher and writer interested in African, environmental, and gender studies. She is currently a Research Fellow at the [[National Institutes of Health]] (NIH). As a woman of [[transwoman|transgender]] experience, she is also a community organizer and advocate addressing [[transgender]] identity, legal, health care and social concerns at the national, state and local levels.<ref name=levels>Housing Works, [http://www.housingworks.org/blogs/detail/half-of-all-state-senators-support-genda-advocates-to-lobby-again-may-/ Supporting Gender Expression Nondiscrimination Act (GENDA).]</ref><ref name=LevelsTwo>Housing Works AIDS Issues Update, [http://newsle.com/article/0/1976856/ GENDA PASSES IN ASSEMBLY: New York Assembly advanced human rights during hour long debate; next stop is the Senate]</ref> Her research and activist work around transgender advocacy and [[Ball culture|ballroom community youth]] has been influential in the field of public health. She previously served on the National Advisory Board for the Center of Excellence for Transgender Health<ref name=Board>Center of Excellence for Transgender Health, [http://transhealth.ucsf.edu/trans?page=ab-white Bali White, National Advisory Board Member.]</ref> and managed the [[Center for Disease Control|CDC-funded]] initiatives for young [[transwoman|transwomen]] and [[Men who have sex with men|MSM]] in the [[Ball culture|ballroom community]] at the [[Hetrick-Martin Institute]].
==Background and education== White received her Bachelor of Arts ''magna cum laude'' in Middle Eastern and Asian Languages and Cultures and a Master of Arts in Climate and Society from [[Columbia University]]. During her time at Columbia, she produced a report for the [[United Nations Environment Programme]] on international climate change initiatives. White can speak advanced Kiswahili, intermediate Hindi/Urdu and elementary Spanish and French.
White originally moved to New York City on a summer professional ballet scholarship to the [[Dance Theatre of Harlem]]. She was introduced to the art of [[Kathak]] by her Guru Najma Ayashah. While in [[Rajasthan]] on a Hindi/Urdu scholarship in 2005, Bali studied with Rm honorific [[Shashi Sankhla]], guru-sister to Najma under Pandit Kundan Lal Gangani of the [[Jaipur Gharana]].
==Activism and research== White worked as a Research Consultant for the [[New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene]] and assisted in the completion of ''Transgender Women and HIV Prevention in New York City: A Needs Assessment.''<ref name=Needs>Prepared by Paul Kobrak, assistance by Bali White, [http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/pdf/nyregion/Transgender-Women-and-HIV-Prevention.pdf Transgender Women and HIV Prevention in New York City], 2011.</ref><ref name=More>HIV Health & Human Services Planning Council of New York, [http://www.nyhiv.com/pdfs/NA_Minutes_8-3-09_(PK)_AJS_Final.pdf Needs Assessment Committee.]</ref> White also worked as the Coordinator of Transgender Programming at [[Housing Works]],<ref name=Housing>[[Housing Works]], [http://vimeo.com/1984219 Transgender Program PSA.]</ref><ref name=Works>[[Housing Works]], [http://www.housingworks.org/news-press/detail/bali-white-inspires/ Bali White inspires.]</ref> has been a research assistant for [[National Development and Research Institutes]]'s Transgender Project<ref name=TransProject>National Development and Research Institute, [http://www.ndri.org/transgender/ The Transgender Project.]</ref> and an Assistant Project Director on the House Ball Study (HBS), an ethnographic study of the [[Ball culture|House/Ball community]] (a largely NYC queer of color social network) through [[GMHC]].
White works to change the narrative around relationships among transgender women whose sexual partners are often ignored, to the detriment of effective HIV outreach.<ref name=Partners>White presents at WPATH 2011 Biennial International Symposium “Transgender Beyond Disorder: Identity, Community, and Health,” [http://www.wpath.org/documents/Revised%20Preliminary%20Program,%20August%2012,%202011.pdf Transgender women of color, male partners, and HIV.]</ref> She fought for a program at [[Housing Works]], where partners come in one night a week.<ref name=Body>[http://www.thebody.com/content/art52315.html Bali White].</ref> White has also served on the Board of Directors for the [[Sylvia Rivera Law Project]]<ref name=Sylvia>Sylvia Rivera Law Project, [http://www.champnetwork.org/nygender Gender Spectrum, Gendered Epidemic: The impact of sexism and gender discrimination on women, gay and transgender people in the HIV epidemic.]</ref> and has traveled extensively to meet and network with transgender groups abroad including India and East African countries.
White was an invited panelist on "The System. The Reality. The Solution. Honoring and Protecting the Lives of Black Trans Women" during the [[National Black Justice Coalition]]'s ''[[National Black Justice Coalition#OUT on the HIll|OUT on the Hill]]'' event.<ref name=Out>National Black Justice Coalition [http://nbjc.org/get-involved/out-on-the-hill Out On The Hill.]</ref><ref name=OutTwo>{{cite web|last=Roberts |first=Monica |url=http://transgriot.blogspot.com/2012/09/2012-nbjc-out-on-hill-im-part-of-star.html |title=Honoring and Protecting the Lives of Black Trans Women |publisher=Transgriot.blogspot.com |date=2012-09-05 |accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref>
===Publications=== Scout, Emilia Lombardi, and Bali White. "Letters to the Editors RE: Butch/Femme, F2M, Pregnant Man, TrannyBoi: Gender Issues in the Lesbian Community." ''[[Journal of Gay & Lesbian Mental Health]]'', 14.3 (2010): 257-58. Print.<ref name=Letters>Scout, Emilia Lombardi, and Bali White, [http://www.lgbttobacco.org/files/Letters%20to%20the%20Editor,%20JGLMH%202010.pdf Letters to the Editors RE: Butch/Femme, F2M, Pregnant Man, TrannyBoi: Gender Issues in the Lesbian Community.] ''Journal of Gay & Lesbian Mental Health'', 14.3 (2010): 257-58. Print.</ref>
===Fellowships and awards=== *White was invited to [[The White House]] Office of Public Engagement's A Policy Briefing for Black LGBT Emerging Leaders.<ref name=Policy>Official Invitation, [http://www.sglweeklymag.com/2012/02/official-invitation-white-house.html White House.]</ref> *''Commendation of Excellence'', [[New York City Comptroller|City of New York Office of Comptroller]], For outstanding work and research on transgender and HIV issues, 2009.<ref name=Comp>{{cite web|author=From Housing Works |url=http://www.thebody.com/content/art52315.html |title=Comptroller Thompson Bestows LGBT Pride Award on Transgender Housing Works Staffer |publisher=Thebody.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref> *''Trans Empowerment Award'', Recognized by Queens-based Latino organization for contributions to transgender community, 2009. *''Office of Multicultural Affairs Award'', for service and support to LGBT community at [[Columbia University]], 2006. *''Jon Michael Harrington Humanitarian Award for Activism,'' for advocacy and commitment to the health and empowerment of the [[Ball culture|ballroom community]], 2002.
==External links and citations== *Former editor of [[People (magazine)|People]] magazine's website and a transgender rights advocate [[Janet Mock]] references White in her essay, ''Growing Up Trans: Sisterhood and Shelter at the Hetrick-Martin Institute,'': "Strong women like Ayana, ''Bali'', Danielle, Isis and all of us who bravely prove to live visibly are helping to change the collective portrait of trans people everywhere."<ref name=Mock>[[Janet Mock]], [http://janetmock.com/2011/07/23/transgender-speech-hetrick-martin-nyc Growing Up Trans: Sisterhood and Shelter at the Hetrick-Martin Institute.]</ref> Also referenced in Mock's #GirlsLikeUs [[Pinterest]] page.<ref name=Pin>{{cite web|url=http://pinterest.com/janetmock/girlslikeus/ |title=#GirlsLikeUs Pinterest Page |publisher=Pinterest.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref> *Author David Valentine references White in his book, [https://books.google.com/books?id=VOv-kTqi8tsC&pg=PR12&lpg=PR12&dq=bali+white+transgender&source=bl&ots=tx7Ka-bnWI&sig=oh1n_KFTSaVPdfdZ1hs6p1DdN9Y&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xcpkULLPIIrV0gGj3oGQDQ&ved=0CD8Q6AEwBDge#v=onepage&q=bali%20white%20transgender&f=false ''Imagining Transgender: an ethnography of a category''], Duke University Press, 2007. *White's work is referenced in the ''[[American Journal of Public Health]]'': JPH, Volume 98, Issues 5-8.<ref name=JournalPub>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/search?q=bali+white&btnG=Search+Books&tbm=bks&tbo=1#hl=en&safe=off&tbo=1&tbm=bks&sclient=psy-ab&q=%22Bali+White%22+transgender&oq=%22Bali+White%22+transgender&gs_l=serp.3...17323.18649.1.18696.12.7.0.0.0.0.500.609.0j1j5-1.2.0...0.0...1c.1.toGOemnUaRE&pbx=1&bav=on.2,or.r_gc.r_pw.r_cp.r_qf.&fp=d9029fb208f796d2&biw=1280&bih=790 |title=''American Journal of Public Health'' |publisher=Google.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref> *[[List of Columbia University people]]

{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox Organization |image= BoD Master Logo CMYK.jpg |image_border = |size = 250 |caption = |abbreviation = |motto = |formation = |extinction = |type = |status = |founded = {{start date and age|1760}} |purpose = |headquarters = [[London, UK]] |location = |region_served = UK |membership = |registration_id = 222160 |language = |leader_title = President |leader_name = [[Marie van der Zyl]] |leader_title2 = |leader_name2 = |main_organ = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = nil<ref name=ccbod>{{cite web|url=http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Showcharity/RegisterOfCharities/CharityWithoutPartB.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=222160&SubsidiaryNumber=0|title=Charity overview|work=charitycommission.gov.uk}}</ref> |website = {{URL|http://www.bod.org.uk/}} |remarks = }} The '''Board of Deputies of British Jews''' (historically '''London Board of Deputies''' and '''London Committee of Deputies of British Jews'''), commonly referred to as the '''Board of Deputies''', is the main representative body of [[British Jews|the British Jewish community]]. Established in London in 1760, when seven Deputies were appointed by the elders of the [[Sephardi]] congregation of [[Spanish and Portuguese Jews]] to form a standing committee and pay homage to [[King George III|George III]] on his accession to the throne;<ref name="BODarch">{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/a2a/records.aspx?cat=074-ACC3121_2&cid=0#0|title=The Discovery Service|first=The National|last=Archives|publisher=}}</ref> shortly thereafter the [[Ashkenazi Jew]]ish congregation from Central and Eastern Europe similarly appointed their own "Secret Committee for Public Affairs" to deal with any urgent political matters that might arise,<ref name="RothEngl">[[Cecil Roth]], ''A History of the Jews in England'', [http://www.iamthewitness.com/books/Cecil.Roth/A.History.of.the.Jews.in.England/P.10.The.Reign.of.George.III.1760-1815.htm Chapter 10, The Reign of George III, 1760–1815], 1941</ref> and safeguard the interests of British Jews as a religious community, both in the British Isles, and in the colonies.<ref name="JE'06">Joseph Jacobs, [http://jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/10099-london-committee-of-deputies-of-british-jews London Committee of Deputies of British Jews]</ref> They soon began to meet together as occasions arose, and then on a more frequent basis; by the 1810s they appear to have united as one body.<ref name="BOD-hist">[http://www.bod.org.uk/live/content.php?Category_ID=14 History of the Board] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131023155653/http://www.bod.org.uk/live/content.php?Category_ID=14 |date=23 October 2013 }}, Board of Deputies of British Jews</ref>
The Board has since become a widely recognised forum for the views of the different sectors of the UK [[Jew]]ish community.
==Members and organisation== {{Refimprove section|date=March 2018}} The Board is led by [[Marie van der Zyl]], who succeeded Jonathan Arkush as President in June 2018.<ref name="Women">{{Cite news |url=https://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/women-form-majority-of-board-of-deputies-leadership-for-the-first-time-1.464061 |title=Women form majority of Board of Deputies' leadership for the first time |last=Rocker |first=Simon |date=14 May 2018 |work=[[The Jewish Chronicle]] |access-date=14 May 2018}}</ref>
The chief executive of the Board is [[Gillian Merron]], a former Labour Party politician, who was the Member of Parliament (MP) for Lincoln from 1997 to 2010. From 2009 to 2010 she was Minister of State with responsibility for Public Health at the Department of Health. She leads a team of professional staff including Director of Public Affairs Philip Rosenberg (formerly of Faiths Forum for London).
The Board receives Deputies elected by affiliated individual synagogues, confederations of synagogues, and other organisations within the Jewish community such as charities and youth groups. It serves as the principal reference point for government, the media and wider society. All matters tending to impact on the life of Jews in Britain fall within the Board's remit, including an active interfaith programme. However some Jews have complained that the board speaks for Jews unaffiliated to synagogues without them being represented on the board. Some ultra-orthodox synagogues have chosen not to be affiliated.<ref name=guardian-20120427>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/belief/2012/apr/27/board-of-deputies-british-jews-revolution |title=A weak 'revolution' at the Board of Deputies of British Jews |last=Kahn-Harris |first=Keith |newspaper=The Guardian |date=27 April 2012 |accessdate=20 September 2018}}</ref>
The Board of Deputies offices are co-located with the United Jewish Israel Appeal in Kentish Town.
The Board is the British affiliate of the [[World Jewish Congress]] (WJC), the world-wide umbrella organisation of Jewish communities and is the UK member of the [[European Jewish Congress]] (EJC).
===Past presidents=== [[File:Moses Montefiore 1881.jpg|thumb|right|[[Moses Montefiore]] and his family members dominated the presidency of the Board of Deputies during the 19th century. Sephardic Jews were prominent early on.]] [[File:Walter Rothschild.jpg|thumb|right|[[Walter Rothschild, 2nd Baron Rothschild|Walter Rothschild]] was a president of the Board of Deputies during the early 20th century. The [[Balfour Declaration]] was addressed to him.]] [[File:Lord janner.jpg|thumb|right|[[Greville Janner]] was a president of the Board of Deputies during the late 20th century. He was implicated in a high profile child sexual abuse scandal.]] The most historically notable and longest-serving past president was the Victorian-era banker [[Moses Montefiore]], who in the nineteenth century travelled widely to assist Jewish communities in foreign countries, faced by persecution at the time. A complete list of presidents and interim positions is as follows:<ref name="BODarch"/> {{div col|colwidth=30em}} ====18th century==== * [[Benjamin Mendes Da Costa]] (1760)<!-- piped link possible --> * [[Joseph Salvador]] (1766) * Joseph Salvador (1778) * [[Moses Isaac Levy]] (1789)
====19th century==== * [[Naphtaly Bazevy]] (1801) * no record (1802–1812) * Raphael Brandon (1812) * [[Moses Lindo]] (1817–1829) * [[Mocatta|Moses Mocatta]] (1829–1835) * [[Sir Moses Montefiore]] (1835–1838) * [[David Salmons]] (1838 October–November) * [[Henriques family#The Henriques Branch of Britain|I.Q. Henriques]] (1838–1840) * Moses Montefiore (1840 May–July) * [[Hananel De Castro]] (1840–1841) * Moses Montefiore (1841–1846) * David Salomons (1846 March–August) * Moses Montefiore (1846–1855) * [[Isaac Foligno]] (1855 April–December) * Moses Montefiore (1855–1857) * Isaac Foligno (1855 February–September) * Moses Montefiore (1857–1862) * [[Joseph Meyer Montefiore]] (1862–1868) * Moses Montefiore (1868 June–November) * Joseph Meyer Montefiore (1868–1871) * Moses Montefiore (1871–1874) * Joseph Meyer Montefiore (1874–1880) * [[Arthur Cohen (politician)|Arthur Cohen]] (1880–1895) * [[Joseph Sebag Montefiore]] (1895–1903)
====20th century==== * [[David Lindo Alexander]] (1903–1917) * [[Stuart Samuel]] (1917–1922) * [[Henriques family#The Henriques Branch of Britain|Henry Henriques]] (1922–1925) * [[Walter Rothschild, 2nd Baron Rothschild|Lord Rothschild]] (1925–1926) * [[D'Avigdor-Goldsmid baronets|Sir Osmond d'Avigdor-Goldsmid]] (1926–1933) * [[Neville Laski]] (1933–1939) * [[Selig Brodetsky]] (1940–1949) * A. Cohen (1949–1955) * [[Barnett Janner, Baron Janner|Barnett Janner]]<!-- Not a peer until 1970. --> (1955–1964) * [[Soloman Teff]] (1964–1967) * [[Michael Fidler]] (1967–1973) * [[Samuel Fisher, Baron Fisher of Camden]] (1973–1979) * [[Greville Janner]], [[Queen's Counsel|QC]] (1979–1985) * [[Lionel Kopelowitz]] (1985–1991) * [[Israel Finestein]] (1991–1994) * [[Eldred Tabachnik]], [[Queen's Counsel|QC]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/619244.stm|title=Blair unveils Holocaust memorial plan|date=26 January 2000|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=19 September 2009}}</ref> (1994–2000)
====21st century==== * [[Josephine Wagerman]] [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] (2000–2003), who had been headmistress of the [[Jewish Free School|JFS]] from 1985 to 1993<ref>{{cite web |author=[[Rachel Sylvester]] |title=First woman elected to lead Jewish board|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1348957/First-woman-elected-to-lead-Jewish-board.html |date=17 July 2000 |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] |accessdate=16 August 2012}}</ref> * [[Henry Grunwald (barrister)|Henry Grunwald]] [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] [[Queen's Counsel|QC]] (2003–2009) * [[Vivian Wineman]] (2009–2015) * [[Jonathan Arkush]] (2015–2018) * [[Marie van der Zyl]] (2018–present) {{div col end}}
==Activities== {{Undue weight section|date=November 2016}} ===Interpal allegation=== In 2003, the Board, on its web site, reproduced an extract from a US State Department report that suggested that the aid organisation [[Palestinian Relief and Development Fund]] (Interpal) was helping to fund terrorist organisations. Interpal threatened to sue for [[libel]], whereupon the Board retracted and apologised for its comments.<ref>Dominic Casciani, [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/3135392.stm Islamic charity cleared of Hamas link], [[BBC News]], 24 September 2003.</ref><ref>Dominic Casciani, [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/4564784.stm Top Jewish group 'terror' apology], [[BBC News]], 29 December 2005.</ref>
===Oliver Finegold affair=== The Board became involved in the [[Ken Livingstone#Oliver Finegold controversy|Oliver Finegold affair]] when the Mayor of London, [[Ken Livingstone]] made comments to a Jewish reporter, Oliver Finegold, comparing him or the newspaper he worked for, to a [[concentration camp]] guard. Many individuals and media commentators objected to the remark. Along with the [[Commission for Racial Equality]], the Board filed a complaint to the [[Standards Board for England]], calling for the Mayor to apologise to the reporter. The Mayor made a statement condemning the [[Holocaust]], but stood by his remarks to the journalist, mentioning in passing his belief that the Board of Jewish Deputies only represents a small section of the Jewish community.<ref>Ros Taylor, [http://politics.guardian.co.uk/gla/story/0,,1720137,00.html "Livingstone Suspension Frozen by Judge,"] ''[[The Guardian]]'' 28 February 2006, accessed 9 February 2007.</ref>
===Joint Statement with Muslim Council of Britain=== In 2014 at the height of the Israeli military operation in Gaza, the Board received widespread criticism in the Jewish community for a joint statement issued with the [[Muslim Council of Britain]] (MCB) condemning anti-Semitism and Islamophobia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/123091/board-deputies-approves-controversial-muslim-council-britain-statement|title=Board of Deputies approves controversial Muslim Council of Britain statement|website=www.thejc.com|access-date=2016-07-22}}</ref><ref>The Jewish News, 4 September 2014</ref> The statement with its slogan ‘to export peace rather than import conflict’ proved controversial among some on the conservative wing of the Jewish community but was supported by others on the progressive wing and by groups in inter faith circles.<ref>Report of The Woolf Institute on Faith and Belief in Public Life, 7 December 2015 p. 25</ref> The principle of such a statement was approved by the Board by a majority of over 75% at a meeting of the Board on 21 September 2014. In December 2015, the new leadership of the Board distanced itself from the MCB over the latter’s alleged links to the [[Islamism|Islamist]] [[Muslim Brotherhood]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jewishnews.timesofisrael.com/board-distances-itself-from-muslim-council-of-britain-over-muslim-brotherhood-links/|title=Board distances itself from Muslim Council of Britain over Muslim Brotherhood ‘links’|access-date=2016-07-22}}</ref>
===Suspension of deputy=== In July 2018, the Board of Deputies suspended Roslyn Pine, deputy for [[Finchley United Synagogue]], for six years following comments described as Islamophobic and admitting to holding anti-Arab views.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Welch |first1=Ben |title=Board suspends deputy for six years after investigation into 'Islamophobic' views |url=https://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/board-of-deputies-suspends-roslyn-pine-1.466934 |accessdate=16 August 2018 |work=[[The Jewish Chronicle]] |date=12 July 2018}}</ref>
==Relationship with Scotland's Jews== After [[Scottish devolution]] in 1999, the [[Scottish Council of Jewish Communities]] was formed to give the Jewish Community of [[Scotland]] a single democratically accountable voice in dealings with the [[Scottish Parliament]] and [[Scottish Executive|Executive]], other communities, and other statutory and official bodies. The intention, when it was established was for it to stand in the same relationship to the [[Scottish Government]] as the Board of Deputies of British Jews does to the UK Government. Consequently, the Council is autonomous in matters devolved by the [[Scotland Act 1998|Scotland Act]], such as justice, health and welfare, and community relations, whilst the Board of Deputies speaks for all Britain's Jews on reserved matters such as foreign affairs and equality legislation.

'''''Béarlachas''''' ({{IPA-ga|ˈbʲeːɾˠlˠəxəsˠ}}) is [[Irish language|Irish]] for "[[anglicism]]", or words and phrases used in Irish that are influenced by or stem from the [[English language|English]] language. The term comes from {{lang|ga|Béarla}}, the Irish word for the English language, and refers to both simple anglicisms and [[interlanguage]] forms. It is a result of [[bilingualism]] within a society where there is a dominant, [[Stratum (linguistics)#Superstratum|superstrate language]] (in this case, English) and a minority [[Stratum (linguistics)#Substratum|substrate language]] with few or no monolingual speakers and a perceived "lesser" status (in this case, Irish).
==Types== ''Béarlachas'' exists in many forms, from the direct translation of English phrases to the common form of creating verbal nouns from English words by adding the suffix ''-áil'' (this is also used to form verbs from native roots, such as ''trasnáil'', "cross over", from ''trasna'' "across", ''tuigeáil'' ([[Connacht]], [[Ulster]]) "understanding" ([[Munster]] ''tuiscint''), from ''tuig'' "understand", and so on).<ref>[http://www.gaeltacabac.com/7i.htm Gael-Taca website (Irish language promotion organisation) Examples of 'Béarlachas']</ref> ''Táim ag runáil go dtí an siopa'' ("I'm running towards the shop") is an example of ''Béarlachas'' as "runáil" is a verb created from the English word "run" with the Irish suffix ''-áil'' attached; the traditional Irish for this would be ''Táim ag rith go dtí an siopa''.
[[Calque|Calquing]] also occurs: an English phrase is literally translated into Irish, even though an equivalent Irish phrase already exists.{{Citation needed|date=October 2012}} An example of this is "Moilligh síos" ("slow down" – ''moill'' "delay" + ''síos'' "downwards", calqued from English), instead of the more traditional ''Maolaigh ar do luas'' ("reduce your velocity"), or simply ''Maolaigh!'' ("Slow down!").
==Old borrowings== Many words that are commonly thought by "purists" to be ''béarlachas'' have been a part of the Irish language for a long time, and have become "nativised". True ''béarlachas'' is where the word or phrase is known to be English and is not felt to be native to the Irish language, just as in the English language certain French or Latin words and phrases are used with the speaker's full knowledge of their "non-English" status, such as ''status quo'', ''in situ'', ''plus ça change'', ''c'est la vie'' and ''coup d'état''. At the same time, certain words that are sometimes assumed to be from English are actually from [[Old Norse|Norse]] or [[Norman language|Norman French]], and as such are not ''Béarlachas''. For example:
* ''liosta'': "list" (Norman French ''liste'') * ''aidhm'': "aim" (Norman French {{lang|nrf|aesmer}}; where ''cuspóir'' is considered by some to be the 'native' Irish word) * ''halla'': "hall" (Norse {{lang|non|hǫll}}; the Irish word is ''áras''). * ''véarsa'', ''béarsa'' [the ''b''- form considered to be uneducated dialect]: "verse" (Norman French ''verse'' {{IPA-xx|ˈβʲeːrsə|}}; the Irish word is ''rann'')
Other words are 'early Béarlachas', having entered the language in the 18th and 19th centuries:
* ''praghas'': "price" (also possibly from Norman French ''preis'', ''pris'') * ''dabht'': "doubt" (the Irish words are: ''amhras'', ''gó'')
==Modern concepts== {{Confusing|section|date=March 2011}} <!-- Without saying which words derive from which and what they meant originally, I can't get the point of this section. -->
Words used for foreign inventions, imports, and so on, where a native Irish word does not exist, are often a [[Macaronic language|macaronic]] import as well. These are strictly speaking not ''béarlachas'', but examples of loans from foreign languages. In some cases an Irish word has been developed, and in others it has not. This has been a characteristic of word development in the language for as long as written records exist, and is not limited to ''béarlachas''. In some cases the original Irish word is no longer known, or has a different meaning within the same semantic field:
Modern forms: * ''fón'', ''guthán'' "phone" * ''carr'', ''gluaisteán'' "car" <!--BTW, it's actually Romance "carre" that comes from Celtic "karros", not the other way round. --> * ''badhsuiceal'', ''rothar'' "bicycle"
Older forms: * ''iarla'' (Norse ''jarl''), ''[[tiarna]]'' (Irish) "lord, earl" * ''póg'' (Old Welsh ''pawg''<!-- meaning "peace" or "kiss"? -->, Latin ''(osculum) pacis'' "(kiss of) peace") "kiss" * ''bád'' (Old Norse), ''currach'' (Irish) "boat" * ''garsún'' (Munster), ''gasúr'' (Connacht, Ulster), from [[French language|French]] {{lang|fr|garçon}} "small boy", ''buachaill'' (Irish) "teenager, youth"
==Variation== In some cases, the foreign loan has an official pronunciation in Irish, and a colloquial one based on English; the colloquial form is ''Béarlachas'', while official form is a [[Gaelicisation]] of the foreign word:
* ''ceint'' ({{IPA-ga|kʲenʲtʲ, sˠɛnʲtʲ}}) "cent" * ''bus'' ({{IPA-ga|bˠʊsˠ, bˠosˠ}}) "bus" * ''stádas'' ({{IPA-ga|ˈsˠt̪ˠaːd̪ˠəsˠ, ˈsˠt̪ˠat̪ˠəs, ˈsˠt̪ˠeit̪ˠəsˠ}}, {{IPA-all|ˈsˠt̪ˠæt̪ˠəs, ˈʃt̪ˠæt̪ˠəsˠ|also}}) "status"
The most striking forms of ''Béarlachas'', however, are the names of the letters of the alphabet—the vast majority of which are normally said in the English way, except for {{angbr|a}}—as well as the use of words such as ''bhuel'' ("well"), ''dheas'' ("yes"), ''no'' ("no"), ''jost'' ("just"), ''dhiúnó'' ("you know" – for ''tá's agat'') and ''álraight'' ("all right" – for ''go maith''). Such words are used with their English syntax in Irish:
*'' ''Bhuel'', fanfa mé ''jost'' anseo, ''dhiúnó'', go dtioca tú ar ais. *Well, I'll just wait here, you know, till you come back. *''{{'}}bhFuil tú ''álraight'' ansan, a bhuachaill? - ''No'', nílim ''álraight'' anaonchor.'' * Are you all right there, lad? - No, I'm not all right at all.
Letters that are not traditionally used in [[Irish orthography]] occur (such as {{angbr|j, k, q, v, w, x, y, z}}, as well as {{angbr|h}} at the beginning of words), though in older ''Béarlachas'' words the foreign sounds have been [[Gaelicization|gaelicised]]:
* Jab: Job (beside ''post'' from French, ''obair'' from Latin) * Zú, Sú: Zoo (where ''gairdín ainmhithe'' already exists) * w > bh / v: bhálcaereacht, válcaereacht "strolling, walking"
Most words that begin with {{angbr|p}} in the language are also foreign loans, as {{angbr|p}} did not exist in prehistoric or early Old Irish (such as ''póg'' "kiss" (Old Welsh ''pawg'', Latin ''pacem'' "peace"), ''peaca'' (Latin ''pecatum'' "sin").
==Use in Republicanism== Between the 1970s and the 1990s, [[Irish republicanism|Republican]] prisoners in Long Kesh (now [[HM Prison Maze]]) spoke in Irish. They [[nickname]]d the place "An Gaoltacht", a [[portmanteau word|portmanteau]] replacing the first syllable of the Irish "[[Gaeltacht]]" (Irish-speaking region) with the English "gaol/jail".<ref>[http://www.irishlanguage.net/irish/history.asp IrishLanguage.net - History of the Irish Language]</ref>
It is thought by some that the Republican slogan ''[[Tiocfaidh ár lá]]'' ("Our day will come") is a form of ''Béarlachas'', more idiomatic equivalents being ''Beidh ár lá linn'' ("Our day will be with us") or ''Beidh ár lá againn'' ("We will have our day"). However, the verb ''teacht'', meaning "come", is often used in a variety of phrases to express the "coming" of days, such as ''tháinig an lá go raibh orm an t-oileán d’fhágaint'' ("the day came when I had to leave the island)".
==Similar phenomenon in Scottish Gaelic== The same concept also exists within [[Scottish Gaelic]], in which language it is referred to as {{lang|gd|[[Beurlachas]]}}. Some examples include:
* ''stòraidh'', "story" (instead of ''sgeulachd'') * ''gèam'', "game" (instead of ''cluiche'') * ''tidsear'', "teacher" (instead of the older ''mùin(t)ear'') * ''nurs'', "nurse" (instead of ''banaltram'')
==References== {{Reflist}} {{interlanguage varieties}} {{Irish linguistics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bearlachas}} [[Category:Irish words and phrases| ]] [[Category:Macaronic forms of English]] [[Category:Language contact]]

{{Infobox political party | name = Centrist Alliance | logo = Alliance Centriste logo.png | colorcode = {{Centrist Alliance/meta/color}} | president = [[Philippe Folliot]] | foundation = 27 June 2009 | ideology = [[Liberalism]]
[[Pro-Europeanism]] | headquarters = 31, rue de Tournon
[[6th arrondissement of Paris|Paris VI]] | international = | website = {{URL|http://www.alliancecentriste.fr}} | country = France | native_name = Alliance centriste | predecessor = [[Rally the Centrists]] | position = [[Centrism|Centre]]{{cite web|author=Wolfram Nordsieck |url=http://www.parties-and-elections.eu/france.html|title=France|website=Parties and Elections in Europe|date=2017}} | national = | european = | europarl = | seats1_title = [[National Assembly of France|National Assembly]] | seats1 = {{Composition bar|2|577|hex={{Centrist Alliance/meta/color}}}} | seats2_title = [[Senate of France|Senate]] | seats2 = {{Composition bar|9|348|hex={{Centrist Alliance/meta/color}}}} | seats3_title = [[European Parliament]] | seats3 = {{Composition bar|1|74|hex={{Centrist Alliance/meta/color}}}} | seats4_title = [[Regional councils of France|Presidency of Regional Councils]] | seats4 = {{Composition bar|0|17|hex={{Centrist Alliance/meta/color}}}} | seats5_title = [[Departmental councils (France)|Presidency of Departmental Councils]] | seats5 = {{Composition bar|0|101|hex={{Centrist Alliance/meta/color}}}} | colours = Dark, Blue, and Orange }} The '''Centrist Alliance''' ({{lang-fr|Alliance centriste}}) ('''AC''') is a [[centrism|centrist]] [[list of political parties in France|political party]] in [[France]]. It was founded in June 2009 by [[Jean Arthuis]], a former member of the [[Union for French Democracy]] (UDF){{cite web|url= http://www.lepoint.fr/actualites-politique/2009-06-27/nouveau-parti-politique-jean-arthuis-elu-president-d-alliance-centriste/917/0/356408|title= Jean Arthuis élu président d'"Alliance centriste"|publisher= Le Point.fr|date= 27 June 2009|language=fr}} and currently Member of [[European parliament]], where he also serves as chair of the Committee on Budgets. The party is seen as a successor to Arthuis' [[Rally the Centrists]] (''Rassembler les centristes'') political association, whose main tenet was to re-create the UDF which was dissolved upon creation of the [[Democratic Movement (France)|MoDem]] and the [[New Centre]]. Because of Arthuis' high standing within the [[Centrist and Republican Union|Centrist Union]] group in the French Senate, the AC has ten Senators but only two deputies. ==Elected officials== *'''Members of the European parliament:''' [[Jean Arthuis]] *'''Deputies:''' [[Thierry Benoit]], [[Philippe Folliot]] *'''Senators:''' [[Muguette Dini]], [[Yves Détraigne]], [[Françoise Férat]], [[Adrien Giraud]], [[Joseph Kergueris]], [[Jean-Claude Merceron]], [[Anne-Marie Payet]], [[Daniel Soulage]], [[François Zocchetto]].{{fr icon}} [http://www.alliance-centriste-champagne-ardenne.fr/2009/12/28/les-chefs-de-file-investis-par-alliance-centriste/#more-324 List of AC parliamentarians on the Champagne-Ardenne federation website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091231024204/http://www.alliance-centriste-champagne-ardenne.fr/2009/12/28/les-chefs-de-file-investis-par-alliance-centriste/#more-324 |date=December 31, 2009 }} In addition, Kergueris is President of the General Council of [[Morbihan]]. Thierry Benoit is general councillor in [[Ille-et-Vilaine]]. ==Leadership== * President: [[Jean Arthuis]] (2009 – 2016)
[[Philippe Folliot]] (2016 - present day) ==Footnotes== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{fr icon}} [http://www.alliancecentriste.fr Centrist Alliance official website] {{French political parties}} [[Category:Political parties in France]] [[Category:Centrist parties in France]] [[Category:Pro-European political parties]]

{{Infobox film | name = Confrontation at Concordia | image = | caption = Still shot from documentary depicting Concordia students | director = Martin Himel | producer = Martin Himel | writer = Martin Himel | narrator = Martin Himel | music = | cinematography = | editing = | distributor = | released = 2003 | runtime = 45 minutes | country = Canada | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Confrontation at Concordia''''' is a documentary film by Martin Himel which documents the [[2002 Netanyahu protest at Concordia University|September 2002 protest]] at [[Concordia University (Montreal)|Concordia University]] in [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], Canada.{{cite journal|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_7074/is_16/ai_n28249285/pg_2/?tag=content;col1|title=The debate on Canadian campuses: bringing back democracy and the spirit of scholarship|first=Howard|last=Stein|journal=Inroads: A Journal of Opinion|volume=Winter-Spring|year=2005}} The film chronicles how pro-[[Palestinian nationalism|Palestinian]] student activists staged a [[direct action]] aimed to cancel the former [[Israel]]i [[Prime Minister]] [[Benjamin Netanyahu]]'s address on campus. The talk by the prime minister had been organized by [[Hillel: The Foundation for Jewish Campus Life|Hillel]], a Jewish student organization.[http://www.camera.org/index.asp?x_context=46&x_review=9 Confrontation @ Concordia] ([[CAMERA]]){{cite video| people =Martin Himmel| title =Confrontation at Concordia (documentary)}} [http://www.cbsc.ca/english/decisions/2004/040511appendixA.pdf Transcript] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120711055139/http://www.cbsc.ca/english/decisions/2004/040511appendixA.pdf |date=2012-07-11 }} (Appendix A to CIII-TV (Global Television) re Confrontation at Concordia (CBSC Decision 02/03-1340, -1368, -1514 and -1530, April 26, 2004)) The documentary portrays the events that took place in a negative light, and reportedly contributed to the ensuing media debate over them. The Concordia Student Union (CSU) responded by taking legal action against its producer.[http://jcpa.org/article/anti-israeli-activity-at-concordia-university-2000-2003/ Anti-Israeli Activity at Concordia University 2000-2003] by Corinne Berzon, [[Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs]], September 25, 2008 ==Synopsis== The documentary opens with scenes of the violence at the event, depicting fighting between protesters and Jewish students attempting to enter the venue. This is followed by an interview with student Samir Elitrosh, a leader of the Solidarity for Palestinian Human Rights and the leader of anti-Israel violence who was later suspended. It also features interviews with Concordia's Hillel president Yoni Petel and Concordia rector Frederick Lowy, and concludes with a discussion of what it sees as the growing trend of anti-Israel activities on North American campuses.[http://www.jewishindependent.ca/archives/Aug03/archives03Aug22-03.html Film examines violence. Professor offers ways to counter hate on campuses] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928162032/http://www.jewishindependent.ca/archives/Aug03/archives03Aug22-03.html |date=2007-09-28 }} by Kyle Berger (Jewish Independent) August 22, 2003 The documentary presents footage of pro-Palestinian activists breaking windows and pushing and shoving to block the only entry to the lecture hall. The pro-Palestinian students had objected strongly to Netanyahu's attempt to give scheduled speech.[http://www.cjnews.com/viewarticle.asp?id=8166 Charges against Netanyahu protester dropped]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} By Janice Arnold (Canadian Jewish News) In a segment of the film [[Prime Minister]] [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] described the conduct of Concordia students:
... what you have is an implantation in North America of this same unforgiving fanaticism that says "we will not allow the engagement of a contest of ideas, we will not allow a free market of ideas," which is precisely a microcosm of the problem that we have in these societies that spawn and produce terrorism. They rigidly control what their people hear and see so that they can control what they think and feel. And this is the essence of the problem. If the real solution to this fanaticism is ventilation, the aeration of various ideas, then you got a whiff of the underlying root cause of terrorism in Concordia. That is the unwillingness to have a free exchange of ideas. The root cause of terrorism is [[totalitarianism]].
In the film, Thomas Hecht, a former member of the Board of Governors of Concordia University and a [[the Holocaust|Holocaust]] survivor, states: {{quote|This was [[antisemitism|anti-Semitism]]. I was the object of their hatred ... which expressed itself with placards; with a kind of venom which I have not seen on the streets of a city since the horrible days of occupied, Nazi-occupied Europe. What happened on the 9th of September was really a dark day for Concordia. And I think that the university will have to suffer the consequences of this. It will not come, the change will not come from one day to the other. The perception of Concordia will not be that of an institution where [[freedom of speech]] can be freely expressed. Because the way these thugs behaved was not any better than the people who were condemned for such behaviour in 1939 in Europe. When I tried to enter, somebody approached me with a masked person. They had a hood or something, or a burka, or a shador on, I don't know if it was man or a woman and they kicked me in the groin. They spat on me. I felt as though I was in Bratislava in 1939 again, where they also spat on me because I was a Jew. But that was Czechoslovakia under German occupation and I was experiencing something which I thought would never happen again: that I was guilty of something because I was Jewish. I was guilty of wanting to hear a speech.}} In response to allegations of [[antisemitism]], Elitrosh, leader of the Solidarity for Palestinian Human Rights, averred that one can be anti-Israel without being antisemitic. He stated that "Judaism existed before the state of Israel." ==Controversy== The film set off a series of debates regarding student politics and whether anti-Israeli/pro-Palestinian political rallies on campuses were anti-Semitic. ===Criticism=== Antonia Zebisias, media critic of the ''Toronto Star'' criticized the documentary for making hyperbolic comparisons between the riot and [[Kristallnacht]], for giving the president of Hillel more air time than was given to the Palestinian side, and for not supporting many of its contentions with facts. It also noted the potential conflict of interests due to the fact that the film was aired on [[Global TV]] which is owned by CanWest, the media outlet which in part helped organize the invitation of Netanyahu to speak.[http://friends.ca/News/Friends_News/archives/articles06290301.asp Global Documentary Seems Unfair] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061004072635/http://www.friends.ca/News/Friends_News/archives/articles06290301.asp |date=2006-10-04 }} After the documentary was broadcast on ''Global Television'', [[Canadian Broadcast Standards Council]] (CBSC) received a number of complaints relating to the program. The complaints were considered under the provisions of the Canadian Association of Broadcasters' (CAB) Code of Ethics and the Radio and Television News Directors Association of Canada (RTNDA) Code of (Journalistic) Ethics. The CBSC concluded that none of the provisions of the either the CAB Code of Ethics or the RTNDA Code of (Journalistic) Ethics were breached.[http://www.cbsc.ca/english/decisions/decisions/2004/040511.htm CIII-TV (Global Television) re Confrontation at Concordia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050422193005/http://www.cbsc.ca/english/decisions/decisions/2004/040511.htm |date=2005-04-22 }} Canadian Broadcast Standards Council National Conventional Television Panel. (CBSC Decision 02/03-1340, -1368, -1514 and -1530). Decided April 26, 2004 ===Support=== Himel has defended the film, arguing that "In my Concordia, we did interview the Arab student, as well as the Jewish student leader Patrick Amar. But [[Discordia (film)|Discordia]], besides interviewing Elatrash, interviewed a [[self-hating Jew]] who agreed with the Arabs. There was no interview with Amar or any other self-respecting Jewish spokesperson."[http://www.bnaibrith.ca/article.php?id=590 Documentary Producer Martin Himel Keynote Speaker at Jabotinsky Memorial] by Rick Kardonne, B'nai Brith Canada, August 6, 2004, archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20101213193028/http://bnaibrith.ca/article.php?id=590 here]. ==Awards== ''Confrontation at Concordia'' was selected as the best international documentary at the 2003 [[New York International Independent Film and Video Festival]].[http://www.nyfilmvideo.com/2003/july/awards.htm New York International Independent Film & Video Festival] ==See also== * ''[[Discordia (film)|Discordia]]'' ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://tjctv.com/?p=152 ''The Jewish Channel's'' review of the film] {{DEFAULTSORT:Confrontation At Concordia}} [[Category:2003 films]] [[Category:Canadian films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Canadian documentary films]] [[Category:Student politics]] [[Category:Documentary films about Montreal]] [[Category:Concordia University]] [[Category:Documentary films about the Israeli–Palestinian conflict]] [[Category:2000s documentary films]] [[Category:Jews and Judaism in Montreal]]
