'Toy Story 4' Pushed to 2019 |last=McClintock |first=Pamela |date=October 26, 2016 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |access-date=October 26, 2016}} including an [[IMAX]] release as part of Disney's new distribution deal with IMAX, but only in 2D.{{cite news |last1=Vlessing |first1=Etan |title=Disney Renews Film Slate Deal With Imax Through 2019 |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/disney-renews-film-slate-deal-imax-2019-978402 |accessdate=February 23, 2017 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=February 22, 2017}} It is accompanied by Pixar's short film ''[[Bao (film)|Bao]]''.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-43749225 |title=Bao is Pixar's first film by an Asian woman |date=April 13, 2018 |publisher=BBC}} The film's release was originally scheduled for June 21, 2019, but the date was moved forward after Pixar handed the 2019 release date over to ''[[Toy Story 4]]'', after its production fell behind schedule. === Marketing === A 53-second teaser trailer premiered on November 18, 2017 during [[ESPN]]'s broadcast of ''[[College GameDay (football)|College GameDay]]''. It received 113 million views in its first 24 hours, becoming [[List of most viewed online trailers in the first 24 hours|the most viewed trailer]] for an animated film, and the 7th most-viewed trailer overall.{{cite news |title=Incredibles 2 is the most-viewed animated movie trailer ever |url=http://ew.com/movies/2017/11/20/the-incredibles-2-trailer-views |accessdate=November 22, 2017 |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] | date=November 20, 2017}} A new sneak peek premiered during the [[2018 Winter Olympics]] on February 14.{{cite news |title=Special Look at 'Incredibles 2' Coming February 14 During the Winter Olympics |url=http://www.pixarpost.com/2018/02/incredibles-2-olympic-preview.html |accessdate=February 8, 2018 |work=[[Pixar Post]] | date=February 8, 2018}} On April 13, a new trailer was released.{{Cite news |url=http://ew.com/movies/2018/04/19/incredibles-2-siblings/ |title='Incredibles 2' exclusive: Meet the siblings who want to legalize superheroes |work=Entertainment Weekly |access-date=May 13, 2018}} === Merchandise === An ''Incredibles 2'' graphic novel and comic miniseries was published by [[Dark Horse Comics]] in 2018. The graphic novel, titled ''Incredibles 2: Heroes at Home'', was written by Liz Marsham and illustrated by Nicoletta Baldari. A comic miniseries, titled ''Incredibles 2: Crisis in Mid-Life! & Other Stories'', was written by [[Christos Gage]] and [[Landry Walker]], and illustrated by [[Gurihiru]], [[J. Bone]], Andrea Greppi and Roberta Zanotta.{{cite news |title=Dark Horse announces Incredibles 2 tie-in comics |url=http://ew.com/books/2018/03/19/incredibles-2-tie-in-comics-dark-horse/ |accessdate=May 11, 2018 |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] | date=March 19, 2018 |first=Christian |last=Holub}}{{cite web |url=https://www.cinemablend.com/news/2389681/an-incredibles-2-graphic-novel-and-a-comics-miniseries-are-coming-later-this-year |title=An Incredibles 2 Graphic Novel And A Comics Miniseries Are Coming Later This Year |last=Holmes |first=Adam |date=March 2018 |access-date=May 22, 2018 |work=Cinema Blend}}{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2018/03/19/incredibles-2-tie-in-comic-explores-the-parr-familys-domestic-life |title=Incredibles 2 Tie-in Comic Explores the Parr Family's Domestic Life |last=Gilyadov |first=Alex |date=March 19, 2018 |access-date=May 22, 2018 |work=[[IGN]] | publisher=[[Ziff Davis, LLC]]}} In May 2018, a prose novel was released entitled ''Incredibles 2: A Real Stretch: An Elastigirl Prequel Story'', which focuses on the life of the character Elastigirl before the events of the first film. A [[Lego The Incredibles|Lego video game adaptation]] of both films was released on the same day as ''Incredibles 2''.{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2018/03/28/lego-the-incredibles-announced-first-gameplay-details-revealed |title=Lego the Incredibles Announced, First Gameplay Details Revealed |last=Dornbush |first=Jonathon |work=[[IGN]] | publisher=[[Ziff Davis, LLC]] | date=March 28, 2018 |access-date=March 28, 2018}} === Home media === ''Incredibles 2'' was released on [[digital copy]] on October 23, 2018, and on [[4K UHD]] Blu-ray, [[Blu-ray]], and [[DVD]] on November 6, 2018.{{cite web |url=https://comicbook.com/movies/2018/08/19/disney-pixar-incredibles-2-home-release-date-bluray-DVD/ |title='Incredibles 2' Home Release Date Revealed |date=August 25, 2018 |access-date=August 25, 2018}} == Reception == === Box office === {{As of|2018|11|25|df=US}}, ''Incredibles 2'' has grossed $608.5 million in the United States and Canada, and $632.3 million in other territories, for a total worldwide gross of $1.241 billion. On July 1, 2018, the film passed $648 million at the worldwide box office, surpassing the $633 million the original film made in its entire theatrical run. It is currently the [[List of highest-grossing films in the United States and Canada#Not adjusted for inflation|ninth highest-grossing film of all-time domestically]] and the highest-grossing animated film domestically.{{cite web |url=https://www.boxofficemojo.com/alltime/domestic.htm |title=All Time Domestic Box Office |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] | accessdate=August 5, 2018}}{{cite web |url=https://www.boxofficemojo.com/genres/chart/?id=animation.htm |title=Animation Movies at the Box Office |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] | accessdate=August 5, 2018}} The film crossed the $1 billion mark on July 30, 2018, becoming the seventh animated film and the 36th film of all-time to reach the milestone. It was also the fifth animated Disney film, the third Pixar film, and Disney's 18th film overall to gross $1 billion worldwide, as well as the fastest animated film to gross $1 billion, doing so in 46 days, surpassing ''[[Minions (film)|Minions]]'' (49 days).{{cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2018/07/incredibles-2-crosses-1-billion-global-box-ofice-disney-pixar-1202436374/ |title='Incredibles 2' Powers Past $1 Billion At Worldwide Box Office |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] | publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] | date=July 31, 2018 |first=Nancy |last=Tartaglione |accessdate=July 31, 2018}} On August 12, the film surpassed ''[[Toy Story 3]]'' ($1.067 billion) to become the highest-grossing Pixar film worldwide.{{cite web |url=https://www.boxofficemojo.com/franchises/chart/?id=pixar.htm |title=Pixar movies on box office |website=[[Box Office Mojo]] | date=August 12, 2018 |accessdate=August 13, 2018}} ==== United States and Canada ==== In April 2018, early box office projections had ''Incredibles 2'' grossing $110 million in its opening weekend in the United States and Canada.{{cite web |url=https://pro.boxoffice.com/long-range-tracking-incredibles-2-pixar-avengers-infinity-war-update/ |title=Long Range Tracking: 'The Incredibles 2' |last=Robbins |first=Shawn |work=[[BoxOffice (magazine)|BoxOffice]] | date=April 20, 2018 |accessdate=April 21, 2018}} In May 2018, a month before the film's release, tracking revised to an opening weekend of $140 million or more.{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2018/film/box-office/incredibles-2-box-office-tracking-1202820940/ |title=Box Office: 'Incredibles 2' Tracking for Supercharged $140 Million Opening |last=McNary |first=Dave |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date=May 24, 2018 |accessdate=May 25, 2018}} A week prior to the film's opening, [[Fandango]] reported that pre-sale of tickets for the film had exceeded that of previous mid-year blockbusters ''Finding Dory'', ''[[Wonder Woman (2017 film)|Wonder Woman]]'', ''[[Spider-Man: Homecoming]]'' and ''[[Suicide Squad (film)|Suicide Squad]]'' at the same point in their release cycles.{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2018/film/news/incredibles-2-fandango-presales-1202835825/ |title='Incredibles 2' Outpaces 'Finding Dory' as Fandango's Top Animated Pre-Seller |first=Dave |last=McNary |date=June 7, 2018 |accessdate=June 7, 2018 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]}} By the week of its release, opening weekend projections had reached upwards of $150 million.{{cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2018/06/incredibles-2-tag-superfly-weekend-box-office-preview-1202408829/ |title='Incredibles 2' Poised To Squash 'Dory's $135M All-Time Opening Record For Animated Pic |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] | publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] | date=June 12, 2018 |first=Anthony |last=D'Alessandro |accessdate=June 12, 2018}} A day before release, it became Fandango's top pre-selling animated film of all-time, outselling the previous record-holder, ''Finding Dory''.{{cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2018/06/incredibles-2-weekend-box-office-advance-ticket-sales-1202410452/ |title='Incredibles 2' Gobbles 'Dory' To Become Fandango's Top Animated Pic Advance Ticket Seller |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] | publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] | date=June 14, 2018 |first=Anthony |last=D'Alessandro |accessdate=June 14, 2018}} The film grossed $18.5 million from Thursday night previews, increasing weekend projections to as high as $174 million. The previews set the record for an animated film, doubling ''Finding Dory''{{'}}s $9.2 million, and were higher than the likes of fellow superhero films ''Spider-Man: Homecoming'', ''[[Thor: Ragnarok]]'' and ''[[Justice League (film)|Justice League]]''. It made $71.6 million on its first day, including previews, the best-ever for an animated film (besting ''Dory''{{'}}s $54.7 million by 31%) and 14th highest all-time. It went on to debut to $182.7 million, the eighth best opening of all-time, far ahead of ''Finding Dory''{{'}}s animated record of $135.1 million and more than the entire lifetime gross of Pixar's ''[[A Bug's Life]]'' ($162.8 million), ''[[Cars 3]]'' ($152.9 million) and ''[[The Good Dinosaur]]'' ($123.1 million).{{cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2018/06/incredibles-2-tag-superfly-weekend-box-office-1202411262/ |title='Incredibles 2' Record $183M Beats 'Captain America: Civil War' Opening & Lifetime Totals Of 'Cars 3', 'A Bug's Life' |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] | publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] | date=June 18, 2018 |first=Anthony |last=D'Alessandro |accessdate=June 18, 2018}}{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/incredibles-2-crushes-animation-record-with-180-million/2018/06/18/127b6722-730e-11e8-bda1-18e53a448a14_story.html |title=Box Office Top 20: 'Incredibes 2' record inches higher |work=[[The Washington Post]] | agency=[[Associated Press]] | date=June 18, 2018 |accessdate=June 21, 2018}} The film set animated records for its Monday and Tuesday grosses, making $23.9 million (beating the $23.4 million made by ''[[Shrek 2]]'' in May 2004){{cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2018/06/incredibles-2-monday-box-office-record-animated-movie-1202413253/ |title='Incredibles 2's $23.9M Monday Is Best Ever For An Animated Movie |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] | publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] | date=June 19, 2018 |first=Anthony |last=D'Alessandro |accessdate=June 19, 2018}} and $27.1 million (beating ''Finding Dory''{{'}}s $23.1 million), respectively. Its Tuesday gross also set a June record, topping ''[[Jurassic World]]'' ($24.3 million in 2015).{{cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2018/06/incredibles-2-june-tuesday-box-office-record-1202414089/ |title='Incredibles 2' Flies To Best Tuesday In June With Near $27M |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] | publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] | date=June 20, 2018 |first=Anthony |last=D'Alessandro |accessdate=June 20, 2018}} By Thursday, its seventh day of release, the film had grossed $269.4 million, topping the entire lifetime domestic gross of the original, not accounting for inflation ($261.4 million). In its second weekend the film dropped 56% to $80.9 million, finishing second behind newcomer ''[[Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom]]'' ($148 million), marking the first time two films opened to over $100 million in back-to-back weekends.{{cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2018/06/jurassic-world-fallen-kingdom-opening-weekend-box-office-1202415529/ |title='Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom' With $150M Reps Uni's 2nd Highest Opening Ever – Sunday |last=D'Alessandro |first=Anthony |work=[[Deadline Hollywood]] | date=June 24, 2018 |accessdate=June 24, 2018}} It remained in second place in its third and fourth weekends, grossing $45.5 million and $29 million, respectively.{{cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2018/06/jurassic-world-fallen-kingdom-uncle-drew-sicario-weekend-box-office-1202419558/ |title=At $2.5B To Date, Summer's B.O. Is More Colossal Than Ever Imagined; Dinos Still Rule With $60M+ Second Weekend |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] | publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] | date=July 1, 2018 |first=Anthony |last=D'Alessandro |accessdate=July 1, 2018}} On July 7, its 23rd day of release, the film crossed $495 million, passing ''Finding Dory'' to become the highest-grossing animated film and Pixar's highest-grossing film of all-time domestically,{{cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2018/07/ant-man-and-the-wasp-opening-box-office-overperform-marvel-1202422128/ |title='Ant-Man And The Wasp' Shrinks A Tick To $76M+ Opening, But Still 34% Bigger Than Original – Early Sunday Read |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] | publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] | date=July 8, 2018 |first=Anthony |last=D'Alessandro |accessdate=July 8, 2018}} and the following day became the first animated film to gross over $500 million domestically.{{cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2018/07/dwayne-johnson-skyscraper-hotel-transylvania-3-ant-man-and-the-wasp-box-office-1202424852/ |title='Hotel Transylvania 3' & Dwayne Johnson's 'Skyscraper' Vie For Prime Box Office Real Estate |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] | publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] | date=July 11, 2018 |first=Anthony |last=D'Alessandro |accessdate=July 14, 2018}} On September 2, its 80th day of release, it became the first animated film to gross over $600 million domestically.https://screenrant.com/incredibles-2-first-animated-film-600-million-domestic/ ==== Internationally ==== Outside North America, the film made $51.5 million from 25 countries in its opening weekend, for a global debut of $231.5 million. Mexico was the largest debut with $12.3 million, followed by Australia ($7.7 million) and Russia ($5.4 million).{{cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2018/06/jurassic-world-fallen-kingdom-china-opening-second-weekend-international-box-office-1202411418/ |title='Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom' Rises To $370M Overseas; 'Incredibles 2' Powers $52M Early Bow – International Box Office |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] | publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] | date=June 17, 2018 |first=Nancy |last=Tartaglione |accessdate=June 17, 2018}} In its second weekend of release the film made $58.6 million from 28 countries, bringing its two-week total to $134.7 million. Its largest market was China where it made $21.2 million, the best ever opening for a Pixar film in the country. It was also released in India where it made $3.3 million.{{cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2018/06/jurassic-world-fallen-kingdom-incredibles-2-deadpool-china-global-international-box-office-1202416393/ |title='Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom' Slurps $711M+ WW; 'Incredibles 2' Has Record Pixar China Bow – International Box Office |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] | publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] | date=June 24, 2018 |first=Nancy |last=Tartaglione |accessdate=June 25, 2018}} In the United Kingdom, the film grossed $12.6 million in its opening weekend, the second biggest opening for Pixar after ''Toy Story 3''.{{Cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/jul/17/incredibles-2-skyscraper-uk-box-office-dwayne-johnson-pixar |title=Incredibles 2's superheroes save the box office as World Cup slump ends |last=Gant |first=Charles |date=July 17, 2018 |website=The Guardian |access-date=July 18, 2018}}{{Cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=intl&country=UK&id=theincredibles2.htm |title=Incredibles 2 (2018) – International Box Office Results – Box Office Mojo |website=''Boxofficemojo.com'' |access-date=July 18, 2018}} {{as of|2018|November|18|df=US}}, The biggest markets in terms of total earnings are the United Kingdom ($73.1 million), followed by China ($51.5 million), Japan ($43.9 million), France ($41.7 million), and Brazil ($37.6 million).{{cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2018/08/mission-impossible-fallout-second-weekend-global-international-box-office-tom-cruise-pulpit-rock-1202439844/ |title=Cruise Control: 'Mission: Impossible – Fallout' Revs To $330M WW – International Box Office |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] | publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] | date=August 5, 2018 |first=Nancy |last=Tartaglione |accessdate=August 5, 2018}} === Critical response === On [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film holds an approval rating of 94% based on 322 reviews, with an [[average rating]] of 7.9/10. The website's critical consensus reads, "''Incredibles 2'' reunites Pixar's family crimefighting team for a long-awaited follow-up that may not quite live up to the original, but comes close enough to earn its name."{{cite web |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/incredibles_2/ |title=Incredibles 2 (2018) |website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] | publisher=[[Fandango (company)|Fandango]] | accessdate=November 17, 2018}} On [[Metacritic]], which assigns a normalized rating to reviews, the film has a weighted average score of 80 out of 100, based on 51 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/incredibles-2 |title=Incredibles 2 Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] | accessdate=June 25, 2018}} Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film a rare grade of "A+" on an A+ to F scale, the same score as the first film, while [[PostTrak]] reported filmgoers gave it a 93% overall positive score and an 83% "definite recommend". Robert Abele of ''[[TheWrap]]'' praised the film, saying: "Whatever the opposite of phoning in a sequel is, that's Brad Bird's progressive-minded, thunderously fun mix of super saves, throwback aesthetics and family comedy."{{cite web |url=https://www.thewrap.com/incredibles-2-film-review-holly-hunter-brad-bird-pixar/ |title='Incredibles 2' Film Review: Pixar's Superhero Family Is Back, Baby – and What a Baby |first=Robert |last=Abele |work=[[TheWrap]] | date=June 11, 2018 |accessdate=June 11, 2018}} A.A. Dowd, writing for ''[[The A.V. Club]]'', felt it was "A sparkling contraption of an animated comedy, funny and often wondrous in its midcentury-modern vision of an alternate America frozen in the amber of a bygone idealism."{{cite web |last=Dowd |first=A.A. |date=June 12, 2018 |title=Brad Bird triumphantly returns to animation, Pixar, and awe-inspiring spectacle with Incredibles 2 |url=https://film.avclub.com/brad-bird-triumphantly-returns-to-animation-pixar-and-1826772007 |work=[[The A.V. Club]] | publisher=[[The Onion]] | accessdate=June 17, 2018}} David Ehrlich of [[IndieWire]] gave the film a "B+", saying: "When the Parrs are pushed out of their comfort zone, Bird settles into his... [after] inciting a Spielberg-level monorail chase that reaffirms Bird's lucid gift for kinetic and character-driven action filmmaking, the movie blasts off and never looks back."{{cite web |last=Ehrlich |first=David |date=June 11, 2018 |title='Incredibles 2' Review: Pixar's Dazzling Sequel Makes Superhero Movies Feel Human Again |url=http://www.indiewire.com/2018/06/incredibles-2-review-brad-bird-pixar-1201973376/ |work=[[IndieWire]] | publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] | accessdate=June 13, 2018}} [[Stephanie Zacharek]] from ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' considered it "bold [and] rapturously entertaining,"{{cite web |last=Zacharek |first=Stephanie |date=June 14, 2018 |title=How Incredibles 2 Shows What It Means to Be Human |url=http://time.com/5311956/incredibles-2-review/ |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] | accessdate=June 17, 2018}} while David Sims at ''[[The Atlantic]]'' dubbed it "dazzling, thought-provoking, and sometimes overwhelming in terms of plotting."{{cite web |last=Sims |first=David |date=June 13, 2018 |title=Incredibles 2 Is a Masterful Action Movie |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2018/06/incredibles-2-is-an-exhilarating-ride/562757/ |work=[[The Atlantic]] | publisher=The Atlantic Monthly Group |accessdate=June 17, 2018}} ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''{{'}}s [[Owen Gleiberman]] called the film "fun but far from incredible" and wrote "It's true that the ''Toy Story'' films, all three of which are fantastic, did variations on the same theme of a toy's obsolescence, but as movies they kept the emotions close to the surface. In ''Incredibles 2'', we never get that rush of feeling."{{cite magazine |last=Gleiberman |first=Owen |url=https://variety.com/2018/film/reviews/incredibles-2-review-holly-hunter-1202837069/ |authorlink=Owen Gleiberman |title=Film Review: 'Incredibles 2' |magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] | date=June 11, 2018 |accessdate=June 11, 2018}} [[Michael Phillips (critic)|Michael Phillips]] of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' gave the film 2.5 out of 4 stars and said, "''Incredibles 2'' is content to punch the clock and stick to straight, bombastic action mode. In that mode, composer Giacchino's music is the most successful element, running nimble, beautifully orchestrated variations on themes that feel familiar in the best ways while retaining their spark. The animation is bright and visually dynamic. The script, well ... if the title were ''Satisfactories 2'', it'd be about right."{{cite news |last1=Phillips |first1=Michael |authorlink=Michael Phillips (critic) |title='Incredibles 2' review: Piling on the action in a 14-years-later sequel |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/movies/sc-mov-incredibles-2-rev-0611-story.html |accessdate=June 11, 2018 |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] | date=June 11, 2018}} Ty Burr for ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' called it a "clattery, unfocused affair that at times is more irritating than fun."{{cite web |last=Burr |first=Ty |date=June 13, 2018 |title=Everyone's favorite superhero family returns in 'Incredibles 2' |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/movies/2018/06/13/everyone-favorite-superhero-family-returns-incredibles/EvrWrggmfayamTpcoJOu1M/story.html |work=[[Boston Globe]] | publisher=Boston Globe Media === [[File:Incredibles 2 screenslaver screen.jpg|thumb|right|Disability advocates have warned that The Screenslaver's hypnotic screens (shown here) may trigger epileptic seizures.]] Many disability advocates, including the [[Epilepsy Foundation]], have raised concerns that scenes with flashing lights, particularly the scene of Elastigirl's fight with the Screenslaver, can trigger seizures in viewers affected by [[photosensitive epilepsy]].{{Cite news |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/incredibles-2-posts-flashing-lights-warning-for-fans-with-epilepsy/ |title=Incredibles 2 posts flashing-lights warning for fans with epilepsy |date=June 18, 2018 |publisher=CNET |access-date=June 20, 2018}}{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/18/movies/incredibles-2-seizures-epilepsy.html |title='Incredibles 2' Moviegoers Warned About Possible Seizures |work=The New York Times |access-date=June 20, 2018}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.epilepsy.com/release/2018/6/epilepsy-foundation-advises-viewer-caution-related-flashing-lights-incredibles-2-and |title=Epilepsy Foundation Advises Viewer Caution Related to 'Incredibles 2' |publisher=Epilepsy Foundation |dead-url=no |access-date=June 20, 2018}} As a result, several theaters posted warnings for audiences.{{Cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/06/18/health/incredibles-2-seizures-warning-bn/index.html |title='Incredibles 2': Theaters post warnings due to seizure concerns |last=CNN |first=Jacqueline Howard, |publisher=CNN |access-date=June 20, 2018}} Disney issued a statement to ''[[USA Today]]'' stating that they appreciated the efforts the theaters had already made in making signs warning people seeing the movie. They then asked theaters to warn audiences about the scene in a memo that read, "''Incredibles 2'' contains a sequence of flashing lights, which may affect customers who are susceptible to photosensitive epilepsy or other photosensitivities."{{Cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2018/06/17/disney-issues-epilepsy-seizure-warning-incredibles-2/708879002/ |title=Disney issues seizure warning about 'Incredibles 2' for fans with epilepsy |work=USA Today |access-date=June 20, 2018}} In response to this, the UK released a re-edited version{{cite web |url=https://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/incredibles-2-film-2 |title=INCREDIBLES 2 – British Board of Film Classification |website=''bbfc.co.uk'' |accessdate=July 29, 2018}} of the film with all affected sequences altered so that any flashing lights and strobe effects now pass the [[Harding test]].{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/veron4ica/status/1015310445098536961 |title=Veronica Lewis (currently at AER) on Twitter |publisher=[[Twitter]] | accessdate=July 29, 2018}}{{Primary source inline|date=August 2018}} == Future == Following the release of ''Incredibles 2'', director [[Brad Bird]] acknowledged that the film's truncated production schedule resulted in many plotlines and ideas he had for the film being cut from the final version. He cited Pixar's decision in October 2016 to swap the release dates of ''[[Toy Story 4]]'' and ''Incredibles 2'', which meant that Bird's film lost a full year of production. Bird stated that the lingering plotlines could lead to a third installment, just as they did with the second. "There were a lot of ideas that we had on this film that could be [used]... whether it's another ''Incredibles'' film, or something else." Cast members including [[Samuel L. Jackson]] and [[Sophia Bush]] have expressed interest in reprising their roles. Producer [[John Walker (film producer)|John Walker]] would not "rule [a third film] out".{{cite web |url=http://ew.com/movies/2018/06/17/incredibles-3-potential-brad-bird/ |title=Could there be an Incredibles 3? Director Brad Bird weighs in |website=[[Entertainment Weekly]] | last=Snetiker |first=Marc |date=June 17, 2018}} == See also == * [[The Incredibles (franchise)|''The Incredibles'' (franchise)]] {{Reflist|group=N}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == {{Wikiquote}} * {{Official website|https://movies.disney.com/incredibles-2}} * {{IMDb title|3606756}} * {{AllMovie title|596222}} {{The Incredibles}} {{Pixar Animation Studios}} {{Brad Bird}} {{Portal bar|2010s|Disney|Animation|Cartoon}} [[Category:2018 films]] [[Category:2018 computer-animated films]] [[Category:2018 3D films]] [[Category:2010s action comedy films]] [[Category:2010s animated superhero films]] [[Category:2010s sequel films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American 3D films]] [[Category:American action comedy films]] [[Category:American animated superhero films]] [[Category:American computer-animated films]] [[Category:American sequel films]] [[Category:American superhero films]] [[Category:Animated action films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Film superheroes]] [[Category:Films about families]] [[Category:Films about shapeshifting]] [[Category:Films directed by Brad Bird]] [[Category:Films scored by Michael Giacchino]] [[Category:Films set on ships]] [[Category:Government in fiction]] [[Category:IMAX films]] [[Category:The Incredibles]] [[Category:Fiction about invisibility]] [[Category:Mind control in fiction]] [[Category:Pixar animated films]] [[Category:Superhero comedy films]] [[Category:Superhero films featuring female antagonists]] [[Category:Theatrically released animated superhero films]] [[Category:Walt Disney Pictures films]]

{{Civil procedure (United States)}} In law, '''intervention''' is a procedure to allow a [[Party (law)|nonparty]], called '''intervenor''' (also spelled '''intervener''') to join ongoing [[litigation]], either as a matter of right or at the discretion of the court, without the permission of the original litigants. The basic rationale for intervention is that a [[Judgment (law)|judgment]] in a particular [[Legal case|case]] may affect the rights of nonparties, who ideally should have the right to be heard.
==Canadian practice== Intervenors are most common in [[appeal|appellate]] proceedings, but can also appear at other types of legal proceeding such as a [[trial (law)|trial]].
In general, it is within the discretion of the court to allow or refuse an application to intervene. There are exceptions to this however (for example, under subrule 61(4) of the Rules of the [[Supreme Court of Canada]], if the court has stated a constitutional question then the attorney general of any province or territory, or of the federal government, may intervene "as of right", i.e. without the need to be granted leave to intervene).
Courts will tend to allow an application to intervene if the applicant will provide a ''different perspective'' on the issues before the court, without ''expanding'' those issues.
Intervenors are permitted in criminal matters as well as civil matters. However, courts sometimes express concern in allowing applications for intervention in criminal matters where the applicant will make arguments against the position of the accused. It sometimes is seen as unfair that the accused in a criminal matter be required to meet arguments from sources other than the prosecution.
There are several distinct reasons why someone might wish to intervene in a proceeding:
*if the proposed intervenor is currently a litigant in a case with legal issues similar or identical to the case at hand; *if the proposed intervenor represents a group of people who have a direct concern in the legal issues raised in a case (for example, if the case involves deportation of a particular individual, an application for leave to intervene might be made by an interest group for the rights of refugee claimants); *if the proposed intervenor is concerned that the court's decision in a particular case might be so broad as to affect the proposed intervenor's interests; in other words it would be an intervention to ensure that the court's ruling does not have "accidental" unintended effects.
It is often said that the role of intervenors is to "assist" the court in making a just decision on the dispute at hand. While it is true that judges sometimes do indicate that intervenors have been of aid to the court in reaching a decision, the use of the word "assist" can be seen as misleading in that it implies the intervenor is acting altruistically. In general, the goal of the intervenor is to influence the court in making its decision, not just to "assist" the court.
Canadian courts (also courts in UK) use the term "[[amicus curiae]]" in a more limited sense. Generally, in Canada, an amicus curiae is someone who has been specifically commissioned by the court to provide a viewpoint which the court believes is necessary and otherwise lacking. By contrast, an intervenor is someone who has applied to the court to be heard on a matter. For example, the ''[[Reference re Secession of Quebec|Quebec Secession Reference]]'' (a case in the Supreme Court of Canada) had one amicus curiae and several intervenors.
==United Kingdom== The [[Attorney General of the United Kingdom (disambiguation)|Attorney-General]] has the right to intervene in a private lawsuit if the lawsuit may affect "the [[Royal prerogative|prerogatives of the Crown]], including its relations with foreign states". Furthermore, the Attorney-General may intervene with leave of the court where "the suit raises any question of [[public policy (law)|public policy]] on which the executive may have a view which it may desire to bring to the notice of the court".<ref>''Adams v Adams'' [1970] 3 All ER 572; [http://uniset.ca/other/cs2/1971P188.html [1971<nowiki>]</nowiki> P 188]; [1970] 3 WLR 934.</ref>
==United States== In the [[United States federal courts]], intervention is governed by [https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/html/uscode28a/usc_sec_28a_02000024----000-.html Rule 24] of the [[Federal Rules of Civil Procedure]].
* Rule 24(a) governs intervention of right. A potential party (called the applicant) has the right to intervene in a case either (1) when a federal statute explicitly confers upon the applicant an unconditional right to intervene or (2) when the applicant claims an interest relating to the property or transaction which is the subject of the [[lawsuit]]. In the second situation, in order to be admitted as an intervenor, the applicant must show that its ability to protect its interest would be impeded by disposition of the case and that its interest is not adequately represented by the current parties to the case. * Rule 24(b) provides for permissive intervention, which is subject to the discretion of the judge hearing the case. An applicant may be permitted by the court to intervene (1) when a federal statute confers upon the applicant a conditional right to intervene or (2) when the applicant's claim or defense shares a common question of law or fact with the main action. Agents of the federal or [[U.S. state|state]] government may be permitted by the court to intervene when a party to a case relies on a federal or state statute or [[Executive order (United States)|executive order]], or any [[regulation]] promulgated thereunder, for its claim or defense.
In both intervention of right and permissive intervention, the applicant must make a timely application to be heard. The applicant cannot sit on its rights; it must intervene as soon as it has reason to know that its interest may be adversely affected by the outcome of the pending litigation. The applicant must [[Service of process|serve]] its [[Motion (legal)|motion]] to intervene on the parties to the case and explain its reasons for intervening in the motion papers. In addition, U.S. federal law does not allow the procedure of intervention to violate the requirements of [[diversity jurisdiction]]. The court must have either diversity jurisdiction or [[federal question jurisdiction]] over the intervenor's claim. [[Supplemental jurisdiction]] is not permitted for intervention claims under {{UnitedStatesCode|28|1367}}(b) when the original claim's federal jurisdiction was based solely on diversity and exercising supplemental jurisdiction over the intervening claim would be inconsistent with the diversity requirements of {{UnitedStatesCode|28|1332}}. However, [[supplemental jurisdiction]] is permitted when the claims are so related that they form the same case or controversy.
In the courts of the State of Texas, a jurisdiction whose rules of civil procedure <ref>http://www.txcourts.gov/media/1435952/trcp-all-updated-with-amendments-effective-january-1-2018.pdf</ref> differ considerably from the rules of civil procedure in federal court, a nonparty may intervene in a pending lawsuit by filing a pleading, which is typically called “plea in intervention” or “petition in intervention” without leave of the court, but any party in the pending lawsuit may object and ask for the intervention to be struck for cause. TEX. R. CIV. P. 60 ("Any party may intervene by filing a pleading, subject to being stricken out by the court for sufficient cause on the motion of any party."). While the Texas rules of civil procedure require no judicial permission and impose no intervention deadline, the common law dictates that a party may not intervene post-judgment unless the trial court first sets aside the judgment. See State v. Naylor, 466 S.W.3d 783, 788 (Tex. 2015).<ref>https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=8002939656385522269&hl=en&as_sdt=6,44</ref> For the same reason, an intervenor must enter the lawsuit before final judgment to have standing to bring an appeal.
==See also== * [[Amicus curiae]] * [[Contribution claim (legal)]]
==References== {{reflist}} Subrin, Stephen N., [[Martha Minow|Minow, Martha L.]], Brodin, Mark S., and Main, Thomas O. ''Civil Procedure: Doctrine, Practice, and Context''. Aspen Publishers, 2004. {{ISBN|0-7355-4086-1}} pp. 834–836.
Justice, [https://web.archive.org/web/20130527222056/http://www.justice.org.uk/resources.php/32/to-assist-the-court To Assist the Court: Third Party Interventions in the UK] (2009)
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070303023258/http://www.scc-csc.gc.ca/actandrules/rules2006/rules2006_e.asp#55 Rules 55 to 59 of the Supreme Court of Canada] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070203182623/http://www.courts.ns.ca/Rules/rule5_8.htm#rule8 Rule 8 of the Civil Procedure Rules – Nova Scotia] * [http://www.collectionscanada.ca/obj/s4/f2/dsk2/ftp03/MQ62193.pdf Intervenors Before the Supreme Court of Canada, 1997–1999: A Content Analysis] (M.A. Thesis by Amanda Jane Burgess) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110401044205/http://www.bsos.umd.edu/gvpt/lpbr/subpages/reviews/brodiefoc.html book review of ''Friends of the Court: The Privileging of Interest Group Litigants in Canada''] - link is not direct * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110610070359/http://publish.uwo.ca/~irbrodie/publications.html several publications by Ian Brodie on the subject of interveners at the Supreme Court of Canada] *[http://www.justice.org.uk/images/pdfs/To%20Assist%20the%20Court.pdf "To Assist The Court: Third Party Interventions in the UK" (JUSTICE, 2009)]{{dead link|date=July 2012}}

The '''Iraq leak''' (also '''Iraq-gate''', or the '''[[Iraq]] scandal''') is a series of events that began on 6 March 2003 from a statement given by [[Anneli Jäätteenmäki]], leader of the [[Finland|Finnish]] [[Centre Party (Finland)|Centre Party]], in a televised election debate prior to the [[Finnish parliamentary election, 2003|2003 parliamentary election]]. Jäätteenmäki accused [[Paavo Lipponen]], the then [[Prime Minister of Finland]], of attaching Finland to [[George W. Bush]]'s '[[coalition of the willing]]' that was in preparation for the [[2003 war in Iraq]].{{ref|hs}} Lipponen had visited [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]] on 9 December 2002.
According to Jäätteenmäki, Finland had taken part in a meeting where 'those countries that had promised cooperation and aid' had been invited. It was later discovered that Jäätteenmäki had acquired the information from secret foreign ministry documents, which she had received from [[Martti Manninen]], an advisor to the [[President of Finland]] and a member of Jäätteenmäki's party.
Prime Minister Lipponen's actions were suggested to be influenced by the fact that Finland was about to sell [[AMOS]] mortars to the U.S. military as part of its [[Land Warrior]] program.
The [[Left Alliance (Finland)|Left Alliance]] member of parliament [[Jaakko Laakso]], together with other representatives, had posted a public question on Lipponen's statements in Washington already on 19 December 2002.{{ref|laakso}} There was no public inquiry on the matter, even though the documents cast doubt on the legality of [[Mortar (weapon)|mortar]] deals during the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|2001 war in Afghanistan]]. The [[Green League|Green]] member [[Ulla Anttila]] and others questioned an authorisation to export arms that was granted to [[Patria (company)|Patria]]-[[Land Systems Hägglunds|Hägglunds]] shortly before the war started.{{ref|anttila}}
The Centre Party won the [[Finnish parliamentary election, 2003|parliamentary election]] and became the largest party in the [[Parliament of Finland|Parliament]]. Jäätteenmäki was [[Anneli Jäätteenmäki's Cabinet|appointed]] Prime Minister of Finland by President [[Tarja Halonen]] on 17 April 2003.{{ref|cabinet}} However, the lack of confidence in Jäätteenmäki caused by her use of secret documents in the campaign and her flat-out denial before the Parliament of having solicited them, despite incriminating evidence, forced her to resign as Prime Minister on 24 June. Jäätteenmäki claimed to have received the documents unexpectedly and without solicitation, which Manninen denied. A new cabinet was formed by [[Matti Vanhanen]], who also became the leader of the Centre Party.{{ref|vanhanen}} Manninen was also sacked from his job as advisor to the president.
On 19 December 2003, criminal charges were pressed against Martti Manninen for leaking secret documents and against Anneli Jäätteenmäki for incitement and aid to the same. Manninen was found guilty, and had to pay 80 [[day fine]]s, but Jäätteenmäki was not found guilty, as she did not specifically request the documents.
[[David Schlaefer]], spokesperson for the U.S. Embassy in Helsinki, denied in 2003 after Jäätteenmäki's resignation that there was ever any understanding on cooperation or assistance between Finland and the U.S. during Lipponen's meetings in Washington, stating at a conference at University of Helsinki that "it is simply not true, it did not happen."
== Catchphrases originated from the scandal == {{Refimprove|date=November 2006}} A number of comments made by Prime Minister Jäätteenmäki during the unfolding of her part of the scandal remain as popular phrases in Finland. Among the most memorable are: * "I have two ears and I have heard all kinds of things." Jäätteenmäki's explanation for how she got hold of the secret information. Now used in the shortened form "I have two ears." * "I try to speak as truthfully as I can." Jäätteenmäki to reporters at Helsinki airport in early June 2003. Became a popular example of "politician's ethics". * "I hadn't asked for them and they came to me as a surprise." Jäätteenmäki defending herself before Parliament on the charges that she had asked for the secret documents from Manninen or somebody else. This is often alluded to with ''pyytämättä ja yllätyksenä'', "unrequested and as a surprise".
== References == #{{note|hs}} [http://www2.helsinginsanomat.fi/uutiset/juttu.asp?id=20030307KO4 HS: Jäätteenmäki: Suomi liitetty USA:n rintamaan] #{{note|laakso}} [http://www.eduskunta.fi/faktatmp/utatmp/kk_1096_2002_p.htm Eduskunta: KK 1096/2002 vp - Jaakko Laakso /vas ym.] #{{note|anttila}} [http://www.eduskunta.fi/faktatmp/utatmp/kk_47_2003_p.htm Eduskunta: KK 47/2003 vp - Ulla Anttila /vihr ym.] #{{note|cabinet}} [http://www.presidentti.fi/fin/instituutio/instituutio_80503_su.pdf Tasavallan presidentin kanslia: Tasavallan presidentti instituutiona] #{{note|vanhanen}} [http://www.valtioneuvosto.fi/vn/liston/base.lsp?r=17553&k=fi Valtioneuvoston luettelo Suomen hallituksista]

{{Infobox executive government |government_name = Jewish National Council |nativename = הוועד הלאומי |date = 1920 |state = [[Yishuv]], [[Mandatory Palestine]] |leader_title = president of the council |responsible = [[Assembly of Representatives (Mandatory Palestine)|Assembly of Representatives]] }} The '''Jewish National Council''' ('''JNC''') ({{lang-he|ועד לאומי}}, ''Va'ad Le'umi''), also known as the '''Jewish People's Council''' was the main national executive institution of the Jewish community ([[Yishuv]]) within [[Mandatory Palestine]]. ==History== The JNC was established in 1920, the same year as the [[Histadrut]] and the [[Haganah]] were founded, in order to conduct Jewish communal affairs. Its first chairman was [[Rabbi]] [[Abraham Isaac Kook]]. Jewish communal affairs were generally conducted through a hierarchy of representative organizations, including the JNC. Another of these organizations was the National Assembly, which had three hundred members. These three hundred delegates selected from among themselves the members of the National Council, which was also known as the Va'ad Leumi.Cleveland, William L., and Martin P. Bunton. A History of the Modern Middle East. Boulder: Westview, 2013. 232. Print. [[File:Ben-Zvi, Yaacov Zrubavel, Ben-Gurion, Brenner, Aharon Reuveni.jpg|thumb|Left to right; seated – [[Yosef Haim Brenner]], [[David Ben-Gurion]], [[Yitzhak Ben-Zvi]]; standing – A. Reuveni, [[Ya'akov Zerubavel]] (1912)]] The members of the JNC also participated in meetings of the Zionist General Council. The organization represented almost all major Jewish factions, however a few smaller groups at first objected to the creation of centralized leadership. Notably, [[Agudat Israel]] joined only in 1935.{{Citation needed|date=June 2014}} It was announce only in 1946 that the Sephardic Jews and the Zionist Revisionists, would stop refusing to participate in the JNC.[http://www.jta.org/1946/04/22/archive/arab-mayor-of-hebron-submits-petition-to-transjordan-ruler-asking-anschluss JTA.org. Arab Mayor of Hebron Submits Petition to Transjordan Ruler Asking “anschluss” April 22, 1946]{{verify source|date=February 2017}} ===Role in the establishment of Israel=== The Political Department of the JNC was responsible for relations with the Arabs, ties with the [[Jewish Agency]] and negotiations with the British government. As the yishuv grew, the JNC adopted more functions, such as education, health care and welfare services, internal defense and security matters, and organized recruitment to the British forces during [[World War II]]. In the 1940s, departments for physical training, culture and press and information were added. {{Citation needed|date=October 2011}} The report of the [[Anglo-American Committee of Inquiry]] issued in 1946, stated:
"The Jews have developed, under the aegis of the Jewish Agency and the JNC, a strong and tightly-woven community. There thus exists a virtual Jewish nonterritorial State with its own executive and legislative organs..."[http://www.mideastweb.org/angloamerican.htm The report of the Anglo-American Committee of Inquiry] Ch. VIII. The State Within the State.
When the [[Israel|State of Israel]] was established in 1948, this departmental structure served as a basis for the government ministries. On March 2, 1948, the New Jewish Council:
" begins work on organization of Jewish provisional government" {{cite web | url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/37211825/Palestine-Israel-US-State-Department-Records | title=Palestine Israel US State Department Records | publisher=University Publications of America | year=1987 | accessdate=October 25, 2011 | author=Nanette Dobrosky | pages=37}}
On May 14, 1948, (the expiration day of the British Mandate), its members gathered at the [[Tel Aviv Museum of Art]] and ratified the [[Declaration of Independence (Israel)|proclamation declaring the establishment of the State of Israel]]. The members of the JNC formed the [[Provisional government of Israel|provisional government]] of the nascent State of Israel. == Departments == * The Political Department * The Education Department * The Health Department * The Communities Department * The Rabbinate * The Social Welfare Department == Presidents == * 1920–1929 [[David Yellin]] * 1929–1931 [[Pinhas Rutenberg]] * 1939–1944 [[Yitzhak Ben-Zvi]] * 1944–1948 [[David Remez]] ==See also== {{portal|Mandatory Palestine|Politics}} * [[History of Israel]] * [[Jewish Agency for Israel]] * [[Zionism]] * [[Henrietta Szold]] == References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * [https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/History/vaad.html Vaad Leumi] at the [[Jewish Virtual Library]] * [http://www.mongabay.com/reference/country_studies/israel/GOVERNMENT.html Country Studies Program], [http://countrystudies.us/israel/16.htm] at the [[Library of Congress]] * [http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Facts%20About%20Israel/History/Facts%20About%20Israel-%20History Facts About Israel-History] at MFA * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060218110448/http://www.wzo.org.il/en/resources/view.asp?id=1622 The Cry of the Children in Palestine] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050913220237/http://www.wujs.org.il/activist/learning/judaism/wars.shtml Between the World Wars] {{Zionism}} {{Mandatory Palestine topics}} [[Category:Politics of Mandatory Palestine]] [[Category:History of Israel]] [[Category:Jewish organizations in Mandatory Palestine]] [[Category:Provisional governments]] [[Category:1920 establishments in Mandatory Palestine]] [[Category:1948 disestablishments in Mandatory Palestine]]

[[File:John Edwards, official Senate photo portrait.jpg|thumb|Senator [[John Edwards]]]] {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2012}} [[John Edwards]] is a former [[United States Senate|United States Senator]] from [[North Carolina]] and a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] vice-presidential and presidential candidate who, in August 2008, admitted to having had an extramarital affair. The affair was initially reported in late-2007 by ''[[The National Enquirer]]'' (a U.S. [[supermarket tabloid]] newspaper), but was given little attention outside the tabloid press and political [[blogosphere]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Where's HuffPo on Edwards?|url=http://media.nationalreview.com/post/?q=ZTkxNDRmN2NjMmVmODM4YmFkOWNmZGZkZThlNzdjNjk=|work=NRO Weekend|publisher=National Review Online |accessdate=December 15, 2012|author=Greg Pollowitz|date=24 July 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Elizabeth Edwards' Chutzpah Plus--Obama, from Cling to Ping!|url=http://www.slate.com/id/2189635/#mrsechutzpah|work=Slate|publisher=The Slate Group, a Division of the Washington Post Company |accessdate=December 15, 2012|author=Mickey Kaus|date=28 April 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Sometimes, There's News in the Gutter |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/10/opinion/10pubed.html|accessdate=December 15, 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=9 August 2008|author=Clark Hoyt}}</ref> The ''Enquirer'' cited claims from an anonymous source that Edwards had engaged in an affair with [[Rielle Hunter]], a [[filmmaker]] hired to work for his presidential campaign, and that Hunter had a child from the relationship. [[ABC News]] reported that [[Andrew Young (political operative)|Andrew Young]], a member of Edwards' campaign team, stated that Edwards asked him to "Get a doctor to fake the DNA results ... and to steal a diaper from the baby so he could secretly do a DNA test to find out if this [was] indeed his child."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/john-edwards-admits-fathered-child-affair/story?id=9620812 |title=John Edwards Admits He Fathered Rielle Hunter's Child During Affair |publisher=Abcnews.go.com |date=January 21, 2010 |accessdate=November 27, 2011}}</ref>
The allegations were initially published in late-2007 and were denied by both Edwards and Hunter. Young claimed paternity of Hunter's daughter, although no father is listed on the child's birth certificate, and Young has subsequently denied it.
In July 2008, several U.S. [[mainstream media]] news outlets cited the allegations in relation to Edwards' future political career, as well as in relation to his chances of being selected as a [[running mate]] in [[Barack Obama]]'s [[Barack Obama presidential campaign, 2008|2008 presidential bid]]. Then, on August 7, 2008, Edwards admitted to ABC News correspondent, [[Bob Woodruff]], that he did have an extended affair with Hunter, but denied that he was the father of Hunter's baby girl.<ref name=ABC8Aug>{{cite news |first1=Rhonda |last1=Schwarz |author2=Woodruff, Brian |title=Edwards Admits Sexual Affair; Lied as Presidential Candidate |url=http://www.abcnews.go.com/Blotter/story?id=5441195&page=1 |publisher=[[ABC News]] |date=August 8, 2008 }}</ref> Hunter's sister claimed that Edwards was the father and publicly asked Edwards to take a paternity test to determine whether the child was his.<ref>{{cite news |first1=Rhonda |last1=Schwartz |authorlink= |author2=Brian Ross |title=Mistress' Family Challenges Edwards to Take DNA Test |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/story?id=5546813&page=1 |work=ABC News |date=August 9, 2008 }}</ref>
On January 21, 2010, Edwards issued a statement admitting that he was the father of Hunter's child.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/34963767/ns/today-today_people/ |title=Edwards admits fathering child with mistress |publisher=Today.msnbc.msn.com |date=January 21, 2010 |accessdate=November 27, 2011}}</ref> After the admission from Edwards that he fathered a child with Hunter, Edwards' wife, [[Elizabeth Edwards]], announced a separation from her husband, with an intention to file for divorce.<ref>{{cite news|title=John Edwards and wife separate|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/01/27/us-usa-politics-edwards-idUSTRE60Q65P20100127 |accessdate=December 15, 2012 |newspaper=Reuters|date=27 January 2010|agency=Reuters}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Elizabeth Edwards tells her sister: 'I've had it.' |url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/entertainment/post/2010/01/elizabeth-edwards-tells-her-sister-ive-had-it-/1#.UMx2xnNes-s |accessdate=December 15, 2012 |newspaper=USA Today|date=27 January 2010|author=Ann Oldenburg|agency=USA TODAY, a division of Gannett Co. Inc}}</ref> On January 25, 2010, the existence of an explicit sex tape, featuring Edwards and Hunter, was publicly reported.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/2020/John_Edwards_Scandal/john-edwards-made-sex-tape-abortion-plea-aide/story?id=9680626 |title=John Edwards Made Sex Tape, Abortion Plea, Aide Says |publisher=Abcnews.go.com |date=January 28, 2010 |accessdate=November 27, 2011}}</ref>
When Edwards first admitted to the affair, he stated that Elizabeth was in remission from [[breast cancer]]. However, it became clear that the affair was still ongoing, even after he and his wife made a joint announcement that her cancer had returned and was found to be incurable. Elizabeth Edwards died on December 7, 2010.
==Rielle Hunter and the Edwards campaign== {{Main|Rielle Hunter}} In December 2006, ''[[Newsweek]]'' reported that Hunter had been hired by the Edwards campaign to produce a series of [[webisode]]s that portrayed behind-the-scenes life on the campaign trail.<ref>{{cite video | title = John Edwards Webisode 1: Plane Truths | medium = internet video | publisher = Webcastr.com | year = 2008 | url = http://www.webcastr.com/videos/politics/edwards-webisode-1-plane-truths.html | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080808022222/http://www.webcastr.com/videos/politics/edwards-webisode-1-plane-truths.html | archivedate = August 8, 2008 | df = mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite video | title = John Edwards Webisode 2: The Golden Rule | medium = internet video | publisher = Webcastr.com | year = 2008 | url = http://www.webcastr.com/videos/politics/john-edwards-missing-webisode-2.html | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080914072859/http://www.webcastr.com/videos/politics/john-edwards-missing-webisode-2.html | archivedate = September 14, 2008 | df = mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite video | title = John Edwards Webisode 3: Plight of Uganda | medium = internet video | publisher = Webcastr.com | year = 2008 | url = http://www.webcastr.com/videos/politics/missing-edwards-webisode-3-plight-of-uganda.html | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080809135138/http://www.webcastr.com/videos/politics/missing-edwards-webisode-3-plight-of-uganda.html | archivedate = August 9, 2008 | df = mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite video | title = John Edwards Webisode 4: Plugs | medium = internet video | publisher = Webcastr.com | year = 2008 | url = http://www.webcastr.com/videos/politics/missing-edwards-webisode-4-plugs.html | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080809135143/http://www.webcastr.com/videos/politics/missing-edwards-webisode-4-plugs.html | archivedate = August 9, 2008 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> Hunter had [[Pitch (filmmaking)|pitched]] the idea of creating the series to Edwards when she met him at a [[Bar (establishment)|bar]] in [[New York City|New York]], where the politician was attending a business meeting.<ref>{{cite news |first=Jonathan |last=Darman |title=Politics 2008: John Edwards, Untucked |url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/44245 |work=[[Newsweek]] |date=December 25, 2006 }}</ref> The campaign paid Hunter's production company, Midline Groove, over [[United States dollar|USD]]$100,000 for the short documentaries<ref name=WCNC1Aug>{{cite news |first=Stuart |last=Watson |title=No father on alleged love child's birth certificate |url=http://www.wcnc.com/news/topstories/stories/wcnc-073108-krg-birthcertificate.1f42367b.html |publisher=[[WCNC-TV]] |date=August 1, 2008 }} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> that were uploaded to [[YouTube]] upon completion. In 2006, ''[[Business Week]]'' included one of the episodes as a feature in a [[web video]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Catherine |last=Holahan |title=The Year in Web Video |url=http://images.businessweek.com/ss/07/01/0102_videostory/source/1.htm |work=[[Business Week]] }}</ref>
The first apparent mention, in print form, of a possible Edwards/Hunter affair, appeared in the ''[[New York Post]]'' on August 27, 2007. The page-six feature published a [[blind gossip]] item<ref>{{cite news |title=Just Asking|url=http://www.nypost.com/seven/08272007/gossip/pagesix/just_asking.htm |work=[[New York Post]] |date=August 27, 2007 }}</ref> that asked: "Which political candidate enjoys visiting New York because he has a girlfriend who lives downtown? The poll tells her he'll marry her when his current wife is out of the picture." The mention in the ''Post'' started a [[Tabloid (newspaper format)|tabloid]] and [[blogosphere]] investigation that eventually led to accusations against Hunter and Edwards.<ref name=NY11Oct/><ref>{{cite news |first=Alexander |last=Cockburn |authorlink=Alexander Cockburn |title=The Edwards scandal in full |url=http://eurekareporter.com/article/080808-the-edwards-scandal-in-full |work=The Eureka Reporter |date=August 8, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080811011746/http://eurekareporter.com/article/080808-the-edwards-scandal-in-full |archivedate=August 11, 2008 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
In September 2007, Sam Stein, a political reporter for ''[[The Huffington Post]]'', reported that the Hunter web documentaries had been removed from the internet and were no longer accessible. Representatives from the Edwards campaign stated that the material could not be used due to [[campaign finance]] law.<ref name=HuffPo26Sep>{{cite news |first=Sam |last=Stein |title=Edwards Mystery: Innocuous Videos Suddenly Shrouded In Secrecy |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2007/09/26/edwards-mystery-innocuou_n_66070.html |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=September 26, 2007 }}</ref><ref name=York/> Several days later, ''The Huffington Post'' reported that the videos had been reposted to YouTube by an anonymous user.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mystery Edwards Videos Reappear On Web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2007/09/30/mystery-edwards-videos-re_n_66484.html |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=September 30, 2007 |first=Nico |last=Pitney}}</ref>
==Initial ''National Enquirer'' allegations== On October 10, 2007, the ''[[The National Enquirer|Enquirer]]'' published an article claiming that Edwards had engaged in an extramarital [[affair]] with an unnamed female campaign worker. On the same day, Stein published another article in ''The Huffington Post'' that contained additional details about Hunter, including Hunter's name and the web videos that she had produced.<ref name=HuffPo10Oct>{{cite news |first=Sam |last=Stein |title=Scrubbed: Edwards Filmmaker's Deleted Website Raises Questions |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2007/10/10/scrubbed-edwards-filmmak_n_67868.html |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=October 10, 2007 }}</ref> The following day, October 11, ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine published a piece linking Hunter to the ''Enquirer'' allegations.<ref name=NY11Oct>{{cite news |title=John Edwards's Docudrama: The Anatomy of Innuendo |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2007/10/john_edwards_docudrama_the_ana.html |work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |date=October 11, 2007 }}</ref>
Both Edwards and Hunter denied the relationship claims. Edwards said the ''Enquirer'' story was "made up", further stating, "I've been in love with the same woman for 30-plus years," referring to his wife [[Elizabeth Edwards|Elizabeth]], "and as anybody who's been around us knows, she's an extraordinary human being, warm, loving, beautiful, sexy and as good a person as I have ever known. So the story's just false."<ref>{{cite news|title=Edwards Says Tabloid Report of Extramarital Affair Is 'Completely Untrue' |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/story?id=3720191&page=1 |publisher=[[ABC News]] |date=October 11, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080731085405/http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/story?id=3720191&page=1 |archivedate=July 31, 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Breaking News: John Edwards denies affair with campaign worker |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/washington/2007/10/breaking-news-j.html#comment-86116352 |work=Top of the Ticket |publisher=''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' |date=October 11, 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Edwards Denies Tabloid Report Of Affair |url=https://www.usnews.com/usnews/politics/bulletin/bulletin_071012.htm |work=Political Bulletin |publisher=''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'' |date=October 12, 2007 }}</ref> Hunter's attorney issued a denial via [[Jerome Armstrong]], a political blogger and founder of [[MyDD]], stating, "The innuendos and lies that have appeared on the internet (sic) and in the ''National Enquirer'' concerning John Edwards are not true, completely unfounded and ridiculous."<ref>{{cite news |first=Mickey |last=Kaus |authorlink=Mickey Kaus |title=Edwards Walks the Line |url=http://www.slate.com/id/2175509/#nodrudgenostory |work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |date=October 11, 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Ben |last=Smith |title=The Clintonite who owns National Enquirer |url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/bensmith/1007/The_Clintonite_who_owns_National_Enquirer.html |work=[[The Politico]] |date=October 11, 2007 }}</ref> David Perel, the Editor-in-Chief at the ''Enquirer'', did not back down from the paper's allegations, stating, "The original story was 100% accurate."<ref>{{cite news |title=Tabloid's affair rumor dispelled, says John Edwards |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/gossip/2007/11/29/2007-11-29_tabloids_affair_rumor_dispelled_says_joh.html |work=Rush & Molloy |publisher=''[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]'' |date=November 29, 2007 }}</ref>
The ''Enquirer'' published a follow-up story that included a photograph of a visibly [[pregnant]] Hunter on December 19, 2007. The ''Enquirer'' alleged that, according to its anonymous source, Hunter was claiming that Edwards was the father of her child. The article also claimed that Hunter had relocated to a [[gated community]] in [[Chapel Hill, North Carolina]], near Andrew Young, a former official with the Edwards campaign, who had claimed paternity of Hunter's child. As with Hunter's initial denial of the affair, Young's paternity claim had been issued to Armstrong and published on MyDD.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mydd.com/story/2007/12/19/153027/87 |title=Is this really happening? |author=[[Jerome Armstrong|Armstrong, Jerome]] |date=December 19, 2007 |work=[[MyDD]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5Zvb84CP3?url=http://www.mydd.com/story/2007/12/19/153027/87 |archivedate=August 8, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=National Enquirer Enters The 2008 Presidential Race With Edwards Love-Child Story |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2007/12/19/national-enquirerem_n_77603.html |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=December 19, 2007 |first=Danny |last=Shea}}</ref>
[[CBS News]] journalist, [[Bob Schieffer]], asked about the allegations on ''[[Imus in the Morning]]'', stating, "I believe that's a story that we will be avoiding, because it appears to me that there's absolutely nothing to it ... This seems to be just sort of a staple of modern campaigns, that you got through at least one love child, which turns out not to be a love child. And I think we can all do better than this one."<ref>{{cite interview|last=Schieffer |first=Bob |subjectlink=Bob Schieffer |interviewer=[[Don Imus]] |title=Kaus touted Enquirer story about Edwards "love child," didn't note Young's claim in story* that he is the father|url=https://www.mediamatters.org/research/2007/12/19/kaus-touted-enquirer-story-about-edwards-love-c/141994 |publisher=Media Matters for America |date=December 19, 2007}}</ref> [[Mickey Kaus]], a journalist at ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'', speculated that the lack of mainstream coverage was motivated by a desire not to harm Elizabeth Edwards, who was fighting [[cancer]] at the time. Kaus also considered the possibility of news organizations taking a "wait-and-see" attitude, pending the results of the [[Iowa Democratic caucuses, 2008|Iowa caucuses]].<ref>{{cite news |first1=Mickey |last1=Kaus |title=Undernews Underanalysis |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/kausfiles/2007/12/hillary_stunsfour_theories.html#undernewsanalysis|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |date=December 26, 2007}}</ref>
==Hotel encounter with reporters== [[Image:BeverlyHilton01.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Beverly Hills, California|Beverly]] [[Hilton Hotel]], where Edwards encountered the [[The National Enquirer|''Enquirer'']] reporters]] According to Perel, the ''Enquirer'' had received information stating that Edwards would be visiting Hunter and her child at the [[The Beverly Hilton|Beverly Hilton Hotel]] in [[Beverly Hills, California]], on the evening of July 21, 2008, and the paper dispatched several reporters to the hotel. The team of ''Enquirer'' reporters encountered Edwards on the hotel premises sometime after 2 a.m. on the morning of July 22. According to Perel, Edwards, who was not a registered guest of the hotel, retreated from the reporters to a [[washroom]], where he remained until being escorted from the premises by hotel security. The encounter between Edwards and the ''Enquirer'' reporters was later confirmed by a hotel guard interviewed by [[Fox News]]. Edwards' spokespeople did not respond to Fox's request for comment on the incident.<ref name=Fox25Jul>{{cite news |title=Guard Confirms Late-Night Hotel Encounter Between Ex-Sen. John Edwards, Tabloid Reporters |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,391426,00.html |publisher=[[Fox News]] |date=July 25, 2008 }}</ref>
In articles published immediately after the hotel encounter, the ''Enquirer'' claimed to be in possession of evidence showing that Edwards had visited Hunter and her child in the Hilton for several hours, including a videotape of Hunter entering the room, where she allegedly met Edwards, and one of Edwards leaving the same room. However, the paper declined a request from Fox News to release photos or videotape of the incident.<ref name=Fox25Jul/> In an interview with ''[[Radar (magazine)|Radar]]'', Perel said that the ''Enquirer'' would release the photos when "the time is right."<ref name=Radar29Jul>{{cite news |first=Neel |last=Shah |title=Where Are the John Edwards Photos? |url=http://www.radaronline.com/exclusives/2008/07/where-are-the-john-edwards-photos.php |work=[[Radar (magazine)|Radar]] |date=July 29, 2008 }}</ref> The ''Enquirer'' later stated that it had filed a "criminal complaint" against the hotel's security over its conduct during the encounter, but the [[Beverly Hills Police Department]] said that there was no criminal complaint and that only an "incident report" was under investigation.<ref name=Fox25Jul/>
When Edwards was questioned at a [[New Orleans]] event on July 23, 2008, he stated, "I have no idea what you're asking about. I've responded, consistently, to these tabloid allegations by saying I don't respond to these lies and you know that ... and I stand by that."<ref name=Fox25Jul/> On the same day, Hunter appeared on the television program, ''[[Extra (U.S. TV program)|Extra]]'', describing the ''Enquirer'' story as "completely unfounded and ridiculous".<ref>{{cite news |title=John Edwards' Alleged Mistress Speaks! |url=http://extratv.warnerbros.com/2008/07/john_edwards_alleged_mistress.php |publisher=''[[Extra (U.S. TV program)|Extra]]'' |date=July 23, 2008 }}</ref>
On August 6, 2008, the ''Enquirer'' published a blurry photo that allegedly portrayed Edwards holding Hunter's baby.<ref>{{cite news |first=Annette|last=Witheridge|title=John Edwards love child rumours threaten the Barack Obama presidential campaign |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/worldnews/article-1042662/John-Edwards-love-child-rumours-threaten-Barack-Obama-presidential-campaign.html |work=[[Daily Mail]] |date=August 7, 2008 |location=London}}</ref>
